The *Imperially Commissioned Complete Library of the Four Treasuries*
**Masters Section, Volume 14**
*Annotated Ancient Text of the Dragon-Tiger Classic*
**Daoist School**
**Abstract**

We, your ministers, respectfully observe: The *Annotated Ancient Text of the Dragon-Tiger Classic* in three juan was composed by Wang Dao of the Song dynasty. It is prefaced by the author’s own preface and a memorial from Zhou Zhenyi, a Daoist of the Taiyi Palace, submitting the work for imperial consideration, followed by a postscript by the author. Wang Dao’s origins remain unverifiable; he styled himself "Bao Yi Lang, Acting Commander of the Prince of Enping’s Residence," and in his preface described himself as "a mere military officer serving in the princely household." Thus, he was originally a palace guard of the princely establishment who later attached himself to the Daoist tradition.

Chen Zhensun’s *Bibliographic Notes with Explanations* records the *Ancient Text of the Dragon-Tiger Upper Classic* in one juan, unattributed to any author. Wang Dao expanded upon its meaning with annotations and further elucidated his intent through supplementary explanations. The *Classic* is divided into thirty-three chapters: thirteen in the upper juan, six in the middle, and fourteen in the lower. At the end are appended two diagrams—*"Gathering the Celestial Fire Phases"* and *"Gold and Fire Intermingling to Generate the Elixir"*—to clarify the method of practice. The main annotations assert that true lead and true mercury are but the essence of Heaven and Earth and the radiance of the sun and moon, harmonized to emulate creation and refine the divine elixir. They distinguish the authenticity of medicinal ingredients and resolve the differences among minerals. The author also claims to have received the true oral instructions of a master, noting that the circulated versions of the *Dragon-Tiger Classic* contained many errors, which he corrected by reorganizing the text into chapters and fixing the phrasing. During the Chunxi era, he submitted the work for imperial review, explaining that "Dragon-Tiger" signifies the meaning of water and fire—a conventional metaphor in Daoist alchemical texts.

The annotations and explanations frequently cite the *Cantong Qi*, for the discourse on furnace and fire originated with Wei Boyang, whose work remains the "Six Classics" of that tradition. Wang Dao also wrote a *Detailed Annotation of the Cantong Qi*, as mentioned in his postscript, though this work is now lost. Its general purport, however, was likely similar to the present text.

This book is not listed in the *Bibliographic Treatise* of the *History of the Song Dynasty*, leading some to suspect it was forged by Daoist practitioners. Yet, as the antiquity of the *Dragon-Tiger Classic* itself remains unverified, there is little need to investigate the authenticity of the annotations. Moreover, the practices of breath cultivation and life nurturing belong to the reclusive traditions of mountain forests—why, then, would a court alchemist submit such a work to the throne? The man himself is hardly worthy of note; we preserve this text merely because its arguments are coherent.

In the third month of the forty-fourth year of the Qianlong reign, respectfully submitted after collation.

**Chief Compilers:**
Minister Ji Yun
Minister Lu Xixiong
Minister Sun Shiyi

**Chief Collator:**
Minister Lu Feichi

---

**Original Preface to the *Annotated and Exegetical Commentary on the Ancient Text of the Dragon-Tiger Classic***

Your servant Dao states: The learning of the Daoist school encompasses what is called "inner elixir" and "outer elixir," which are truly bound to the essence of life and destiny. Those who attain them achieve, in small measure, the preservation of vitality and extension of years, and in great measure, transcendence into immortality and sagehood. Their disciples have transmitted writings to the world, numbering no fewer than ten thousand scrolls. For the inner elixir, none fail to take spirit and qi as their foundation; for the outer elixir, none fail to take lead and mercury as their origin. An ancient song says:

*Red lead, black mercury—head of the great elixir,*
*When matched in harmony, true cultivation begins.*
*Red lead draws essence, black draws marrow;*
*Resolve this duality, and the medicine is peerless.*
*Merge red into black to preserve long life;*
*Use black in red, and you ascend as a celestial immortal.*
*Inverted, these two form the elixir—*
*Fire and dragon transform into celestial immortals.*

This is the essential method of the outer elixir.

From ancient times to the present, those who study the Dao have all regarded lead and mercury as the great elixir medicine, yet they know not what true lead and true mercury truly are. Since my youth, I have delighted in hearing of such matters, collecting alchemical texts and pondering their meaning day and night, even forgetting sleep and food. Yet these were but words on paper, never elucidated. In the *ren-shen* year of the Shaoxing reign, a Daoist told me that true lead was but the silver ore mined from mountains and stones, and true mercury was the liquid quicksilver extracted from cinnabar. He instructed me to obtain about a catty of each, refine them in a crucible with fire, and await the result. I believed him and thus established a laboratory in the Tianqing Abbey of Guiji, following his instructions to test the method. Years passed, wealth was expended, yet no success was achieved—not because my heart lacked sincerity, but because the method itself was flawed.

In the *jia-shen* year of the Qiandao reign, another Daoist told me that true lead does not reveal its form, and true mercury does not manifest its shape. He further said: "True lead is not silver, true cinnabar is not mercury. Combine these two, divide them into nine portions, and refine them in a tripod with fire to obtain the *Yellow Sprout*. When refined by method, it transforms into *Yellow Chariot* and *Purple Powder*, also called *Dust of the Bright Window*. Ingesting it gathers essence, collects spirit, and eradicates all illness." In my view, this was merely the *Central Elixir* once concocted by Qingxiazi. Not until the *gui-si* year of the Chunxi reign did I encounter a true master, who enabled me to realize that all I had previously obtained was not true lead or true mercury.

An ancient song says:

*True lead is not born within the five metals,*
*It arises in the profound depths before heaven and earth.*
*Another says:*
*The sage seizes the intent of creation,*
*Hand-gripping sun and moon, placing them in the crucible.*
*Gently, the essence of heaven and earth ascends;*
*Gathered, yin and yang converge—*
*Spirit and demon, sun’s soul and moon’s spirit.*
*Whoever recognizes this is a true immortal.*
*Refine and ingest it for over a thousand days,*
*And the body, free of yin, cannot die.*

The true master transmitted to me his secret formula and oral instructions, and in that moment, I awakened as from a dream. Thereafter, I read the books of all schools, and none failed to align; all became clear and luminous. From this, I knew that the sun’s soul and moon’s spirit are true lead and true mercury—arising from formlessness to generate numinous substance. The movement and stillness of the myriad things all proceed from them. If one establishes the crucible, erects the tripod, constructs the divine chamber, and harmonizes the root of sun and moon, mastering the transformations of water and fire without losing the celestial tally, then the great medicine and divine elixir may be obtained.

Over thirty years, I encountered three teachers, and only with the true master did I finally grasp the wondrous Dao. Your servant is but a lowly military officer, serving in a princely household, with meager salary and humble means. I could not gather true companions, procure elixir materials, cast crucibles, construct the divine chamber, or retreat to the mountains and forests to pursue this path. Yet I have focused my heart and will, never forgetting it day or night. Recently, during a moment of leisure, I examined the *Dragon-Tiger Classic* as it circulates in the world and found its errors to be numerous. Thus, I employed what I received from the true master to correct and refine it, dividing it into chapters and verses, composing annotations. I further used the *Cantong Qi* of Wei Boyang to verify its meaning, expanding it into an exegesis to distinguish the authenticity of medicinal materials, the differences among metals and minerals, and to eliminate redundancy while extracting essentials, ensuring coherence from beginning to end. I compiled it into one work of three scrolls: the first scroll contains thirteen chapters, the second six, and the third fourteen, totaling thirty-three chapters. I dare not transmit this to later generations but merely present it to fellow Daoist friends of like aspiration.

Your servant, a man of rustic remoteness, knows no taboos. With reckless audacity and a thousand deaths’ worth of trepidation, I have, through the verification of the eminent scholar Zhou Zhenyi, transcribed and respectfully submitted this work. I humbly pray that in Your Majesty’s moments of leisure, You might deign to peruse it, granting me the once-in-a-millennium fortune of fulfilling my lifelong aspiration. This is not merely my private wish but also the entrusted charge of the true master.

Written on the first day of the fourth month in the fourteenth year of the Chunxi reign.

Your servant, the *Baoyi* Lang, Wang Dao, with utmost reverence and awe, bows his head to the ground a hundred times and respectfully presents this preface.

---

**Original Preface to the *Annotated and Exegetical Commentary on the Ancient Text of the Dragon-Tiger Classic***

**Memorial Submitting the *Annotated and Exegetical Commentary on the Ancient Text of the Dragon-Tiger Classic***

Your servant Zhenyi respectfully observes: The *Annotated and Exegetical Commentary on the Dragon-Tiger Classic* in three scrolls, composed by the *Baoyi* Lang Wang Dao, presents matters with clarity and directness, elucidates principles with depth and detail, and profoundly captures the esoteric meaning of the *Cantong Qi* and *Jinbi Jing*. Its teachings on the outer elixir reject the use of the five metals, eight stones, and various miscellaneous minerals as medicinal materials, instead taking the essence of heaven and earth and the radiance of sun and moon, blending them with the transformations of creation to form the divine elixir. This aligns with the words of the Yin Zhenren: "From formlessness, form is generated—this is the returning elixir." The phrases "ordinary lead and ordinary mercury require no manipulation" are entirely consistent with what I have learned.

Though this humble mountain-dwelling Daoist’s study of the Dao is shallow and offers little of value, I have long been versed in the discourse of Daoist texts. An ancient saying goes: "Three broken arms make a good physician." I have known Wang Dao for a long time, and our discussions have been thorough. When he brought his composition to me for verification, it matched in its entirety what I received from my master. Thus, I dare not conceal it but, with trepidation, have transcribed and respectfully submitted it. I humbly hope that in Your Majesty’s moments of leisure, You might glance upon it. From this day forward, I pray that the Imperial Pharmacy be instructed to reject all medicines composed of metals, stones, and miscellaneous minerals, preventing their use by Your Majesty, thereby safeguarding eternal longevity—a great fortune for the realm.

Your servant offers this humble and sincere loyalty, presumptuously encroaching upon Your Majesty’s grace. I humbly beseech Your indulgence, trembling before the awe of Heaven’s might. The depth of my servant’s trepidation is boundless.

Memorial submitted by your servant, Zhou Zhenyi, Daoist of the Yangsu Hermitage in the Taiyi Palace.

---

**Memorial Submitting the *Annotated and Exegetical Commentary on the Ancient Text of the Dragon-Tiger Classic***

*Imperially Commissioned* *Complete Library of the Four Treasuries*

**Annotated and Exegetical Commentary on the Ancient Text of the *Dragon-Tiger Classic*, Volume One**
*By Wang Dao of the Song Dynasty*

**The Divine Chamber: The Pivotal Stanza of the Elixir (Chapter One)**

The Divine Chamber is the pivot of the elixir, the parent of all minerals, where cinnabar and mercury dwell apart.

*Your servant Dao annotates:*
The Divine Chamber is the pivot of the elixir. It mirrors Heaven and Earth, gathering the essence and qi of the sun and moon to form the divine elixir of golden liquid—hence it is called the pivot of the elixir. The *Zhouyi Cantong Qi* states: *"Heaven and Earth are the gates of the Changes."* Such is the meaning. As the parent of all minerals: true lead arises prior to Heaven and Earth, serving as the father of the myriad things and the mother of the hundred spirits—hence it is called the parent of all minerals. The *Zhouyi Cantong Qi* states: *"They are the parents of all hexagrams."* Such is the meaning. As for cinnabar and mercury dwelling apart: cinnabar and mercury originally possess no form or substance; they are concealed within true lead. Only when they obtain the pure essence of the Great Yang can they manifest and transform within the Divine Chamber—hence they are said to dwell apart.

*Your servant Dao exegetes:*
At the inception of the Great Ultimate, primordial qi transformed into Heaven and Earth, dividing into yin and yang to become the sun and moon. From these, humanity and all things were produced, forming the Three Powers. Among them, humans are the most numinous, thus the foremost of the myriad things. In high antiquity, humans dwelled in the world, their lifespans often spanning hundreds or thousands of years. Yet after the Yellow Emperor, lifespans gradually became uneven, with some long and others short. Why is this? It is because humans failed to embody the primordial qi of Heaven and Earth in their conduct, leading to premature harm. Heaven and Earth endure so long because they fully possess the greatness of pure primordial qi, enabling them to follow the four seasons, regulate the five phases, and move in accordance with nature.

The sages of antiquity, comprehending the Dao of Heaven and grasping its workings, harmonized with the primordial qi of nature to nourish their bodies, thereby attaining lifespans akin to Heaven and Earth. Later generations, however, were otherwise: the young, whose blood and qi had yet to mature, were led astray by lust; the old, whose blood and qi were waning, were beset by decline and illness. Even those who came to understand the Dao did so too late, though those who preserved themselves could still prolong their years. Thus, the perfected emulate Heaven and Earth’s transformations, establishing the furnace and tripod to concoct the divine medicine. The aged who ingest it gather essence and guard spirit, returning to youth; the young who ingest it attain immortality all the more swiftly. Therefore, Master Zhenyi states: *"The cultivation of the divine elixir shares the same path as the creation of Heaven and Earth."* When expressed through the imagery of the *Changes*, none do not first gather the root of Heaven and Earth as the foundation of the Great Elixir. They take the movements of Heaven and Earth as the model for the Great Elixir, employing Kan and Li to enact water and fire, traversing Mao and You to govern punishment and virtue, stealing the numerical shifts of the four seasons, and returning them to the palm of the hand. They entrust the mechanisms of yin and yang’s movement and stillness to complete the winter and summer, the yin generation of *Chunhuo*, and the yang effusion of *Xuanxiao*. When in motion, Kun’s lower line transforms into the first nine; when at rest, Qian’s lower line reverts to the first six. These are all the great principles of elixir cultivation.

**Exiting Yang and Entering Yin (Chapter Two)**

Exiting yang and entering yin, their radiance flows to the two directions; the numerical array is three, aligned with the symbols of water and fire.

**Minister Dao’s Annotation States:**

"Exiting yang and entering yin, their radiance flows to the two directions" means yang arises from *zi* and emerges above the earth, traversing *chou*, *yin*, *mao*, and *chen* until it reaches *si*, where yang reaches its apex—thus the Azure Dragon, essence of the sun, shines in the east. Yin descends from *wu* and enters the earth, passing through *wei*, *shen*, *you*, and *xu* until it reaches *hai*, where yin reaches its extreme—thus the White Tiger, splendor of the moon, gleams in the west.

"Numerical array is three, aligned with the symbols of water and fire" means the two entities, Azure Dragon and White Tiger, are both formed by the steaming *qi* of the Vermilion Bird, hence the three agents.

The Great Elixir, from its inception to completion, relies solely on the two symbols of water and fire beyond the divine chamber of true lead—no other substances are intermixed.

**Minister Dao’s Exegesis States:**

In refining the divine elixir of golden liquid, one must first recognize the root origin of the medicinal substances, then verify the advancing and retreating of the firing times. Yang ascends and yin descends, never departing from the *zi* and *wu* directions; the sun’s passage and moon’s return must reside in the *mao* and *you* positions. Employing *Kan* and *Li* to enact water and fire, the Dragon and Tiger transform into husband and wife, returning the sun’s essence to the moon’s cavern. Thus, within lead, cinnabar is produced; when the Vermilion Bird sports in the *Li* palace, mercury arises from cinnabar. Gold arises from *qing* (emotion), mercury from *xing* (nature). When *qing* and *xing* embrace, husband and wife unite, and the golden liquid forms naturally.

Thus, human *qing* and *xing* do not depart from the body, just as the elixir’s cinnabar and mercury both arise within lead. *Qing* and *xing* in humans are not external things, nor are cinnabar and mercury separate from lead. Know then that the sun’s ascent and moon’s descent, yin and yang’s alternation, all occur within Heaven and Earth. Therefore, the essence and marrow of *Qian* and *Kun* constantly gather within the *Qifang* of Cock’s Foot Mountain, becoming the ancestral root of the great medicine and the fundamental stem of the golden elixir.

The sun has three illuminations, the moon three shifts. When the sun emerges in the east and its radiance shines in the west, the true *qi* of the west’s White Tiger, Metal virtue, enters the *Qifang* and transforms into the six *wu*. When the sun sets in the west and its radiance shines in the east, the true *qi* of the east’s Azure Dragon, Wood virtue, enters the *Qifang* and transforms into the six *si*. When the sun and moon align at *wu* and their radiance shines in the north, the true *qi* of the south’s Vermilion Bird, Fire virtue, enters the *Qifang*, coalesces with earth, and takes form as black lead, ever abiding within the *Yaofang*—the root of Heaven, Earth, and the ten thousand things.

Thus, Master Wei said: "The sun conceals its virtue and sinks its brilliance; the moon bestows its virtue and spreads its light. The sun, receiving the moon’s transformation, does not suffer harm." Know then that the true primordial *qi* is the root of Heaven’s and Earth’s generation.

The ancient perfected ones, recognizing that divine substances concealed themselves therein, borrowed their symbolic forms to gather them as the parents of the medicine. They modeled the divine chamber after *Qian* and *Kun*, established the tripod’s legs to symbolize Cock’s Foot, and took the tally of fire as the standard for the four seasons. Returning metal and water to their natural state, they revolved the yang fire to restore the sun’s essence and turned the yin tally to summon the moon’s spirit. Thus, the true *qi* of the three directions converged within the golden crucible, and the supreme harmony of the four symbols congealed within the *Yaofang*. Intermingling in primordial chaos, they were refined within the *Yin’e* until the elixir was complete—all following the transformations of nature.

Nowadays, scholars claim that common mercury can become the golden elixir, and common black lead can serve as the river chariot, leading later generations into delusion, mistaking the false for the real. They devise countless methods, yet grow old without success. Mercury emerges from cinnabar through fire’s transformation, but in principle, it is merely mercury and can never become the golden liquid.

Little do they know that the golden liquid is endowed with Heaven and Earth’s natural *qi*, relying on the pure essence of yin and yang. Yin attaches to the moon as its ruler, its body concealed and nurturing within, corresponding to *wu* and *si* as the parents of the supreme medicine. How could common mercury or the five metals, eight stones, and minerals of mountains and marshes compare to the divine medicine’s mother?

The divine medicine is the treasure for transcending the world and extending life, the ancestor of Heaven, Earth, and the myriad spirits. Yet it is exceedingly difficult for people to recognize. Later learners, using various miscellaneous substances to concoct the golden liquid, fundamentally misunderstand the ancients’ intent. If miscellaneous substances could produce the golden elixir, it would be easily attained. What the ancients called "lead" and "mercury" were direct references to symbolic forms; later generations, failing to grasp their meaning, took cinnabar as lead and mercury as mercury—thus confusing the root with false substances, leading to a thousand failures and ten thousand defeats, never achieving success.

The true lead’s production, as discussed earlier, is entirely based on scriptural excerpts and aligns with the master’s teachings—this is not reckless speculation to mislead later learners. Those who love the Dao should take heed.

**Regulation by the King (Chapter Three)**

Regulation by the king employs martial force to suppress rebellion and civil governance to pacify. Earth flourishes in the four seasons; its virtue reigns supreme. Grasping the sword and sheathing the halberd, it subdues the four directions.

**Minister Dao’s Annotation States:**

"Regulation by the king employs martial force to suppress rebellion and civil governance to pacify" refers to the issuance of decrees—just as a king dispatches edicts to the four directions. Martial force is the fierce fire-phase; civil governance, the gentle fire-phase. This is likened to the firm preparation of the golden crucible and the secure sealing of the spirit-chamber. At the outset, a yielding and compliant fire is applied to draw in the yang harmonizing *qi*, causing it to reside within the crucible-chamber. Later, a fierce fire is employed, and the golden liquid, on the verge of bursting forth, is restrained by the Kun Palace, thus retaining its essence within to complete the transformation. This is akin to a kingdom beset by rebellious subjects, yet through the king’s skillful regulation, they reform their hearts and obey commands, unable to escape.

"Earth flourishes in the four seasons; its virtue reigns supreme" refers to the true earth of *wu* and *ji*. True earth is true lead. True lead can summon the utmost harmonizing *qi* to the Central Palace, so that the *qi* of the Four Symbols—Green Dragon, White Tiger, Vermilion Bird, and Dark Warrior—cannot coalesce into golden liquid without true earth. Earth resides in the Central Palace, hence it is called the Yellow Emperor. Harmonizing *qi* follows the four seasons to generate the myriad things, all of which possess it. The spirit-chamber is the master of harmonizing *qi*, flourishing in the four seasons, able to gather the essence of the sun and moon into the crucible, preventing its dispersion outward. As the *Cantong Qi* states: "Earth flourishes in the four seasons, weaving through beginning and end."

**Minister Dao’s Exegesis States:**

The king governs the realm: internally cultivating civil virtue, externally maintaining martial readiness, modeling after the Three Sovereigns to establish the hundred officials, and following the four seasons to sow the five grains. Thus, the kingdom attains peace and harmony, and harmonizing *qi* arises. The ancients applied the principles of governing the realm to the regulation of golden liquid and divine elixir. At the initial stage, the spirit-chamber must be established. Within the spirit-chamber lies the embryo; beyond the embryo, the golden crucible; and beyond the crucible, the furnace. When all is fully prepared, the essence of the golden liquid is generated, and the utmost harmonizing *qi* converges. The king embodies the Central Palace’s spirit-steed, able to subdue the flowing pearl and prevent its flight. The civil fire is the fire of generation; the martial fire, the fire of consolidation. Together, they enable the golden liquid to reach completion.

In ancient times, after Lord Gongsun ascended, he was matched with the virtue of the Central Earth. Harmonizing *qi* arises from the center, further enveloped by the four seasons, binding metal and water in harmony. The flowing pearl gradually coalesces into divine medicine. The maiden’s flowing pearl, a volatile substance without fixed abode, can only be regulated by earth, returning it to the natural course of transformation.

**Kan-Li Numbers One and Two (Chapter Four)**

Kan-Li numbers one and two: south and north alone form the warp, hence they crown the seventy-two minerals.

**Minister Dao’s Annotation States:**

"Kan-Li numbers one and two": Heaven generates water in Kan, hence the number one governs it; Earth generates fire in Li, hence the number two governs it. "South and north alone form the warp": The north is the extreme of yin, where yang *qi* begins, passing through *zi*, *chou*, *yin*, *mao*, *chen*, and *si* to reach its end. The south is the extreme of yang, where yin *qi* begins, passing through *wu*, *wei*, *shen*, *you*, *xu*, and *hai* to reach its end. Both yin and yang *qi* originate and conclude at *zi* and *wu*, hence south and north alone form the warp. "Hence they crown the seventy-two minerals": True lead is born of precelestial *qi* and takes form in the postcelestial realm, thus it is the chief among all things and the root of the returning elixir.

**Minister Dao’s Exegesis States:**

Among the arts of humanity, none are deemed more wondrous than the transmutation of metals into gold and silver, regarded as worldly treasures. Yet, of those who practice such arts, ten thousand fail for every one who succeeds. Even if success is achieved, it is not a treasure that transcends the world, nor an art that extends life or benefits the realm. Today’s Dao-seekers do not prioritize essence and life, instead blindly following one another, never attaining enlightenment. They remain unaware that the Great Elixir’s path lies entirely in the mutual necessity of yin and yang *qi* to form the supreme medicine. As the *True Person’s Cinnabar Formula* states: "Refining the treasure unites with the utmost subtlety; refining subtlety unites with the utmost numinosity; refining numinosity unites with the utmost spirit; refining spirit unites with the Dao." Such profound words reveal the authenticity or falsity of the golden elixir and the depth or shallowness of its wondrous principles. Without encountering a perfected one’s secret instructions, how can one comprehend the true essence and become a transcendent being?

The *Kan* and *Li* trigrams represent *Li* fire and *Kan* water. The south and north positions are the roots of water and fire. Though divided into two forms, they originate from a single source. Once separated, each embodies its own nature, becoming one in essence and two in manifestation. The perfected one, recognizing this as the natural disposition of heaven, does not rely on artificial combination. Instead, the two symbols are united as one, refined into the supreme treasure. When ingested, it bestows longevity. These two celestial products, free from impurities, are the essence of the sun and moon, the marrow of heaven and earth. As the *Yijing* states: "Heaven displays its images; the sage emulates them." This is returning to the root and reverting to the origin, moving from deliberate action to merge with effortless spontaneity.

Thus, water and fire, *Kan* and *Li*, ascending and descending between south and north, alone head the seventy-two minerals as the foundation of the elixir. By grasping the mechanism of heaven’s generation and destruction and the cycle of the sun and moon, the nature of being and non-being becomes self-evident.

**Hard and Soft, Exterior and Interior (Chapter Five)**

Hard and soft possess exterior and interior; yin and yang are endowed by nature. Metal and fire serve their proper functions; metal and water mutually contain one another. Male and female unite as one body, their application ordered and systematic.

**Minister Dao’s Annotation States:**

"Hard and soft possess exterior and interior; yin and yang are endowed by nature": *Qian* yang is hard; *Kun* yin is soft. They envelop one another, uniting within the spirit-chamber, allowing the natural *qi* of yin and yang and the essence of the sun and moon to converge upon the golden embryo and coalesce into divine medicine. As the *Cantong Qi* states: "*Qian* hard and *Kun* soft unite and envelop one another."

"Metal and fire serve their proper functions; metal and water mutually contain one another": Externally, water and fire are frequently applied; internally, metal and water constantly interact. Watery mercury generates the body of the Green Dragon; metallic essence nurtures the embryo of the White Tiger. As the sprouts gradually manifest, metal and water take form within the spirit-chamber. After prolonged interaction of metal and fire, spirit-water is born within the mother’s womb, and the elixir is completed. Mother and child yearn for one another, and metal and water naturally nourish.

"Male and female unite as one body, their application ordered and systematic": Male and female are also the Dragon and Tiger, *Qian* and *Kun*, the sun and moon, yin and yang, *Kan* and *Li*, husband and wife, water and fire. When male and female intermingle, their essence transforms into beings. If their application follows principle, generation occurs naturally.

The Minister of the Dao comments: The male pertains to the *Li* trigram, the image of the great yang and the sun; the female pertains to the *Kan* trigram, the image of the great yin and the moon. When sun and moon conjoin, metal and water naturally arise, and their natures harmonize in mutual affinity—no external substance is involved. If one forcibly combines them with杂物, the divine medicine will not possess its natural essence. Just as a young man reaching twenty and a maiden coming of age at fifteen yearn for each other, this too is a matter of natural spontaneity. The ancients used this analogy for the great elixir, which is no different from human procreation—both arise from natural essence. Cinnabar and mercury reside within lead’s body, emerging through the stimulation of water and fire, yet they are not external substances. The infant in the mother’s womb likewise arises from water and fire and is not an external substance. The ancients, understanding that these two kinds of essence and nature share the same fundamental root, thus guided the union of Dragon and Tiger’s essence to return and restore the qi of metal and water, naturally forming the supreme medicine. This is what is meant by "the Dao of one yin and one yang." Without natural spontaneity, union cannot occur.

For example, when the two essences of male and female merge in bodily union, the sun’s departure and the moon’s arrival bring about natural transformation—how could external substances be required to conceive a child? This clarifies that the divine medicine must be formed from the *Li* fire and *Kan* water, not from杂物. From this, we know that the true essence of the sun and moon, refined into golden liquid, shares the same principle as human conception, differing only in whether one attains immortality or remains mortal, purity or impurity. The perfected ones, fearing that later learners might fail to grasp the true principle, thus use this analogy as proof. The remaining symbolic correspondences can be understood accordingly.

**Chapter Six: Transformations Already Mysterious**

Transformations already mysterious,
In the end, they return to renew the beginning.
The ninth day sets the measure;
Yang harmony aligns with dawn and dusk.
The cycle completes, matching Heaven’s heart.
Yang lines culminate at *si*;
True yin emerges from *wu*,
From *ding* to *hai* it concludes.

The Minister of the Dao annotates: "Transformations already mysterious, in the end, they return to renew the beginning" means that in refining the great elixir, completion should occur within one month. If the fire timing is imprecise or the crucible is not sealed, the spirit-essence descends minimally, and the golden liquid coagulates slowly, requiring another month. As the *Cantong Qi* states: "When the *jiwei* day arrives at dusk, the end returns to renew the beginning."

"The ninth day sets the measure; yang harmony aligns with dawn and dusk": At the night of the new moon, when the *zi* hour arrives and yang fire is about to rise, this is called the *Fuxi* hexagram, with the yang line emerging at the initial position of *Kun*. From *zi* to *si* is morning and day; from *wu* to *hai* is evening and night. Morning is governed by the *Zhun* hexagram, and evening by the *Meng* hexagram. The *Zhun* and *Meng* hexagrams govern the twelve hours of a day, forming the symbolic structure of the great elixir. One day is governed by two hexagrams, and one month by sixty hexagrams. Initially, it is *Zhun* and *Meng*; finally, it is *Jiwei*. As the *Cantong Qi* states: "The celestial stems set the measure; movement and stillness have morning and evening."

"Matching Heaven’s heart, yang lines culminate at *si*": Yang fire ascends from *zi* to *si*, where yang reaches its peak and yin arises at *wu*. As the *Cantong Qi* states: "In spring and summer, rely on the inner body, from *zi* to *chen* and *si*."

"True yin emerges from *wu*, from *ding* to *hai* it concludes": Yin符 descends from *wu* to *hai*, where yin reaches its peak and yang fire is reborn at *zi*. As the *Cantong Qi* states: "In autumn and winter, act externally, from *wu* to *xu* and *hai*."

The Minister of the Dao comments: The Dao of the great elixir’s transformations begins with the *Qian* and *Kun* hexagrams. Yang fire arises at *zi*, and yin is born at *wu*. Yang reaches its peak at *si*, and yin culminates at *hai*. The twelve lines of *Qian* and *Kun* transform with the twelve hours to produce the golden liquid. Some who attempt the great elixir treat it as a trivial matter, recklessly proceeding, wasting wealth, emaciating their bodies, and exhausting their bones, yet never achieving success. How could they know that the supreme Dao encompasses Heaven and Earth, inhales and exhales yin and yang, revolves the four seasons, steers the sun and moon, manifests the five phases, and cycles day and night to give birth to the myriad things—all governed by the transformations of the supreme Dao?

The perfected ones, understanding the root of the great Dao, can transcend the world. They emulate Heaven and Earth, gather yin and yang, collect the sun and moon’s ethereal souls, and merge the spirit-qi of water and fire to refine the supreme medicine, returning it to spontaneity. Though a thousand scriptures and ten thousand discourses have been left to guide future learners, those who study the Dao still fail to believe. They merely use tangible, material substances to imitate creation, never aligning with the supreme principle. Even if they achieve some success, they cannot restore youth, prolong life, or enable longevity. Instead, they may suffer boils, toxins, and hemorrhages. Those who refine the elixir—can they not be cautious?

**Chapter Seven: Water and Fire Each in Their Place**

Water and fire each in their place,
Holding their boundaries to form cold and heat.
East and west mark benevolence and righteousness;
The five phases transform the four seasons.
Thus yin and yang interact,
Following the Three-in-One to attain principle.

The Minister of the Dao annotates: "Water and fire each in their place, holding their boundaries to form cold and heat": Water is yin, reaching its coldest at *Kan*; fire is yang, reaching its hottest at *Li*. Each holds its place to form winter and summer. As the *Cantong Qi* states: "Rewards and punishments correspond to spring and autumn; dawn and dusk follow cold and heat."

"East and west mark benevolence and righteousness; the five phases transform the four seasons": The east pertains to wood, the source of all things’ growth, hence called benevolence and joy. The west pertains to metal, the agent of all things’ withering, hence called righteousness and anger. The qi of the five phases—metal, wood, water, fire, and earth—transform to regulate the four seasons. As the *Cantong Qi* states: "The hexagram lines contain benevolence and righteousness, manifesting joy and anger in due time."

"Thus yin and yang interact, following the Three-in-One to attain principle": If the numbers of the four images do not lose their timing, the qi of yin and yang will follow water and fire, cold and heat, each attaining its principle.

The Minister of the Dao comments: The sun and moon move in their courses, and cold and heat follow their seasons. As the sun departs, the moon arrives; as the year shifts, the seasons turn. The qi of a year is compressed into a single day’s twelve hours, arranging spring, summer, autumn, and winter to correspond with the four seasons’ phases. Movement and symbolic correspondences must align with timing. If the sun and moon’s measures do not err and the cold and heat’s seasons are precise, the great elixir will surely be achieved.

When the symbolic movements stir internally, one can foreknow the future: essence-qi is born within the chamber, and yin and yang conjoin within the crucible. Once yin and yang’s essence-qi are obtained, the crucible’s interior becomes moist and naturally flows, gradually generating transformations that correspond with the four seasons’ phases. Thus, Chapter Five states: "Spring warms with benevolence; summer heats with propriety; autumn cools with righteousness; winter chills with wisdom." If the four seasons’ qi are harmonious, the year’s affairs will be accomplished.

Moreover, the spring qi is the root of all living things, corresponding to the yang fire phase before noon; the autumn qi is the root of all withering things, corresponding to the yin tally phase after noon. Within the twelve double-hours, *zi*, *chou*, and *yin* belong to spring; *mao*, *chen*, and *si* to summer; *wu*, *wei*, and *shen* to autumn; *you*, *xu*, and *hai* to winter. When the fire phases are circulated through the twelve double-hours in accord with the four seasons and the Five Agents, not deviating by even a hair’s breadth, the crucible’s interior will gradually congeal into liquid gold, and the elixir will surely form.

Thus the song states:
*The sage seizes the intent of Creation’s work,*
*Rolling sun and moon in hand, placing them within the furnace.*
*Gently stirring, inverting heaven and earth’s essence,*
*Gathering yin and yang, the gods and spirits flee—*
*Then one knows the liquid gold and divine elixir.*
Were it not for the Dao’s symbolic correspondences aligning with heaven and earth, and the natural transformations of yin and yang, there would be no accomplishment.

**Chapter Eight: Establishing the Chamber’s Position**

Establishing the chamber’s position—transformation lies within it. The *shen-shi* (spirit-chamber) is the upper and lower crucibles. *Establishing the position* means arranging the intimate union of the feminine and masculine. *Transformation* refers to cinnabar and mercury—these are the two functions of metal and earth. The two functions have no fixed hexagram positions; they spread their wings, soaring through *xu* and *wei*. Their coming and going are not constant, their above and below have no permanence. Dwelling alone, they do not alter, but return to the Central Palace—without earth, they cannot be controlled.

The *Baopuzi* annotates: *"Establishing the chamber’s position—transformation lies within it"* means erecting the spirit-chamber to model heaven and earth. Once heaven and earth are positioned, the radiance of sun and moon shines within them. The *Cantong Qi* states: *"Heaven and earth establish their positions, the Changes move within them"*—this is the meaning. The *shen-shi* is the upper and lower crucibles, corresponding to heaven and earth. The *Cantong Qi* says: *"Heaven and earth are Qian and Kun"*—this is the meaning. *Establishing the position* means arranging the intimate union of the feminine and masculine. Setting up the positions of heaven and earth, Qian and Kun: the upper crucible models heaven, the masculine, and Qian; the lower crucible models earth, the feminine, and Kun. Thus, the upper and lower crucibles, in the union of feminine and masculine, become one. The *Cantong Qi* states: *"Establishing the position means arranging the union of yin and yang"*—this is the meaning.

*Transformation* refers to cinnabar and mercury—these are the two functions of metal and earth. When the crucible is established according to the method of Qian and Kun, the Metal Mother resides in the center, and the Three Powers are complete, giving birth to living mercury. Cinnabar and mercury are the water and fire of Kan and Li, the two functions of Qian and Kun. The *Cantong Qi* states: *"The Changes call Kan and Li the two functions of Qian and Kun"*—this is the meaning. The *two functions without fixed hexagram positions, spreading their wings, soaring through xu and wei* refer to Qian and Kun, the sun and moon. The sun and moon’s ascent and descent, the extraction and addition of water and fire, are not bound to hexagram positions. *Zhang* and *yi* are the position of Li fire in the south; *xu* and *wei* are the position of Kan water in the north. The *Cantong Qi* states: *"The two functions have no fixed positions, circulating through the six voids"*—this is the meaning. *Their coming and going are not constant, their above and below have no permanence* means that water and fire come and go within the spirit-chamber, not fixed in one place. The *Cantong Qi* states: *"Their coming and going are not constant, their above and below have no permanence"*—this is the meaning. *Dwelling alone, they do not alter, but return to the Central Palace* means that if the fire’s extraction and addition follow principle, they will constantly transform and enter the Central Palace as liquid gold. The *Cantong Qi* states: *"Hidden and submerged, they transform within the center"*—this is the meaning. *Without earth, they cannot be controlled; earth envelops all stones as the ancestor of the elixir* means that the Central Palace’s spirit-chamber, refined with true lead, is called the virtue of earth. It envelops the ten thousand things as the ancestor of liquid gold. The *Cantong Qi* states: *"Enveloping the ten thousand things, it is the guiding principle of the Dao"*—this is the meaning.

Minister Dao annotates: The Great Elixir’s Dao relies entirely on lead, silver, cinnabar, and mercury—these two substances. Cinnabar and mercury are the essence of the sun; lead and silver are the splendor of the moon. The method of refining liquid gold does not depart from the profound images of heaven and earth. The previous discussion has already made this quite clear, yet I still fear that students may not comprehend it, so I repeatedly employ analogies. If one understands the words immediately, then cinnabar and mercury can be obtained without labor. Moreover, the presence of cinnabar and mercury in lead is like the presence of human nature and emotions: nature and emotions arise within and respond without, not coming from outside. Cinnabar and mercury are born within and manifest without, also not coming from outside. The two functions of nature and emotions reside within the body; the two names of cinnabar and mercury both dwell within lead. When humans employ nature and emotions, they manifest externally; when lead contains cinnabar and mercury, they operate internally. Thus, one must distinguish their mechanisms. The *Cantong Qi*’s perfected person clearly points out: employ the essence of the sun and moon, combine them to form the medicine—do not use miscellaneous things or other methods.

**Chapter Nine: Mutual Restraint of Being and Non-Being**

Mutual restraint of being and non-being: the Vermilion Bird flames in the void, the purple radiance shines like the sun—cinnabar and mercury perish.

Minister Dao annotates: *Mutual restraint of being and non-being*—*being* is the tiger, *non-being* is the dragon; *being* is white metal, *non-being* is the qi of yin and yang. Using white metal as the spirit-chamber, it cannot generate transformation on its own; only through the ascent and descent of water and fire, circulating the four seasons, can the elixir be formed. Thus, an empty vessel is used to restrain being. The Vermilion Bird is the spirit-fire, steaming from below within the spirit-chamber, from which liquid gold is born through fire. The *Cantong Qi* states: *"To restrain being with non-being, the vessel must be empty"*—this is the meaning. *The purple radiance shines like the sun—cinnabar and mercury perish* means that the purple radiance, the essence of the sun and moon, resides within the divine crucible. Sometimes it transforms into golden radiance, manifesting the light of the sun and moon; sometimes it changes into numinous liquid, revealing the forms of dragon and tiger. Shining within the crucible, it becomes cinnabar and mercury—now vanishing, now appearing; now floating, now sinking—following water and fire, sometimes perishing, sometimes disappearing. The *Cantong Qi* states: *"Thus, one observes their ebb and flow—Kan and Li vanish and perish"*—this is the meaning.

Minister Dao elucidates: The ancients of high antiquity refined mercury alone into the elixir, for they had the dragon but not the tiger. Without relying on the Five Agents or Four Images, modeling heaven and earth, or guarding the union of husband and wife, yin and yang, male and female, they simply took the waxing and waning of yin and yang, Kan and Li’s qi within the body, and the essence of dragon and tiger nurtured within the seven orifices, trusting in spontaneity to unite with the Great Dao. Thus, the ancients all lived long lives without premature death. Since middle antiquity, if one wished to reverse aging, return to youth, prolong life, transcend the world, ascend to the real, and enter the wondrous, one had to install the furnace, establish the crucible, summon the harmonious qi of heaven and earth, and return the splendor of the sun and moon’s essence. Only when the Four Images are secure, the Five Agents complete, the nine revolutions finished, and the three thousand hours fulfilled—then, upon opening the furnace, purple powder congeals like frost, golden radiance shines like the sun. Ingesting it, one attains longevity after heaven and old age. Yet among people today, many know the tiger, but few recognize the dragon. The liquid gold is the Azure Dragon, the ancestor of the east’s Wood virtue—it is the sun.

The Yellow Sprout is the White Tiger, the ancestor of the west’s Metal liquid—it is the moon. The essence and qi of these two substances both possess principles of divine transformation and change. Thus, the scripture states: "The essence of the sun and moon rescues the old and infirm." When refined with proper method and ingested, they too can effect transformation.

As for the transformations of the elixir: cinnabar transforms into mercury, which is yang returning to yin; mercury in turn transforms back into cinnabar, which is yin returning to yang. Though called the "Pure Yang Elixir," when ingested by humans, it assuredly grants longevity. The sages compared the sun and moon’s hun and po to nothing but the positions of Kan and Li, with no other substances involved. Fearing that later generations might fail to grasp the true principle, they spoke plainly to instruct posterity.

**Secret Formula, Chapter Ten: "The Secret Formula Is Not Arbitrarily Composed"**
The secret formula is not arbitrarily composed; its principles are not baseless fabrications. Condensing the profound to extend the subtle, one seeks the numinous and unfolds the trigrams and Five Agents into a classic. Kan is the male essence of Metal; Li is the female radiance of Fire. Metal and Wood contend; Water and Fire overcome each other. Earth flourishes in the Metal domain, and the three substances all perish. The Four Seas converge, bringing about great peace—all through the power of Earth’s virtue in the Central Palace, the achievement of the Yellow Emperor.

Your servant Dao annotates: "The secret formula is not arbitrarily composed; its principles are not baseless fabrications." The sages bequeathed writings to the world without careless composition or reckless speech to mislead later generations. As the *Cantong Qi* states: "Words are not carelessly composed; theories are not idly generated."

"Condensing the profound to extend the subtle, one seeks the numinous": cutting away the superfluous, one grasps the pivotal essentials, verifying the wondrous principles of the sun and moon and aligning with the supreme essence of the numinous. As the *Cantong Qi* states: "Drawing verification to witness efficacy, one measures the numinous."

"Unfolding the trigrams and Five Agents into a classic": embodying the sixty-four hexagrams of the *Zhouyi* to determine the fire times, relying on the Five Agents—Metal, Wood, Water, Fire, Earth—to govern generation and destruction, using the conjunction of the sun and moon to verify the union of husband and wife, and the intercourse of Kan and Li to produce the supreme essence. As the *Cantong Qi* states: "Pursuing the origins of written characters to verify the principles."

"Kan is the male essence of Metal; Li is the female radiance of Fire": Kan conceals the six *wu* (戊), the essence of the moon, the position of male yang residing in the north—the moon is yin. *Wu* is yang, the yang within yin, resembling Metal born within Water—the Tiger. Li conceals the six *ji* (己), the radiance of the sun, the position of female yin residing in the south—the sun is yang. *Ji* is yin, the yin within yang, resembling Mercury born within Fire—the Dragon. As the *Cantong Qi* states: "Kan’s *wu* is the moon’s essence; Li’s *ji* is the sun’s radiance."

"Metal and Wood contend; Water and Fire overcome each other": Metal is white Metal; Wood is red Mercury. When these two contend, they become ever more flourishing. When Water and Fire alternately overcome each other, great brilliance is manifest. As the sun and moon conjoin, hardness and softness mutually arise, and yin and yang attain their principles, then they harmoniously unite. As the *Cantong Qi* states: "The sun and moon are the *Yi*; hardness and softness correspond."

"Earth flourishes in the Metal domain, and the three substances all perish": the three substances—Metal, Wood, and Fire—are enveloped by the tail Fire of the four seasons. After nine revolutions, they are all transformed into the dust of the bright window. As the *Cantong Qi* states: "Earth flourishes in the four seasons, weaving from beginning to end."

"The Four Seas converge, bringing about great peace": inhaling and exhaling the qi of the four directions, they converge within the divine crucible. Drawing the essence of the Dragon and Tiger to become the supreme medicine, completing the work with the Five Earths and wrapping it with the four seasons, one obtains the red, green, black, and white, each performing its function to perfect the divine elixir. As the *Cantong Qi* states: "Green, red, white, and black each reside in their respective directions."

"All through the power of Earth’s virtue in the Central Palace, the achievement of the Yellow Emperor": the Earth virtue of the Central Palace is the supremely harmonious qi of *wu* and *ji*. The Way of the Metal liquid’s transformations all derives from *wu* and *ji*. *Wu* and *ji* reside in the Central Palace, hence called the Yellow Emperor. Those who refine the divine elixir gather the supreme essence of the sun and moon, unite the numinous qi of yin and yang, and when the cycles of the stars are complete and the movements of Water and Fire conclude, all return to the achievement of Earth’s virtue, the Yellow Emperor. As the *Cantong Qi* states: "All derive from the power of *wu* and *ji* in the Central Palace."

Your servant Dao comments: The people of high antiquity did not speak idly; secrets were not transmitted twice. After success, they inscribed it on tablets to guide later generations of those who love the Dao. Moreover, what is conveyed in texts only outlines the general meaning. Now, pointing directly to the source of the great medicine, it enables later generations to dispense with worldly cinnabar and mercury. If one obtains the wondrous method and follows the movements of heaven and earth, yin and yang, and the four seasons to achieve the elixir, this is true yin and true yang. As the *Yinfu Jing* states: "Heaven’s mechanism unfolds, and one does not die." Those who attain this Dao must not recklessly transmit it to others. As the *Cantong Qi* states: "Inscribing feelings on bamboo and silk, one fears leaking the celestial tally, hesitating and sighing, constantly pondering."

Refining the supreme medicine does not exceed Water and Fire. When Water and Fire have intercourse, the qi of the Dragon and Tiger within the crucible harmoniously unite to form the Metal liquid. Thus, true Lead is the father and mother of the golden elixir, the ancestor of numinous Mercury. All transformations and the nurturing of all beings derive from this to come into being. Once true Lead is obtained, the body is stabilized, and the true method of Water and Fire is known—how could the great elixir fail to be achieved?

**Gold and Fire are Lead, Chapter Eleven**
Gold and Fire are Lead. When cinnabar is manifest, nothing is greater than Gold and Fire. Speaking of the profound to perfect transformation: when yang moves, yin dissipates; the primordial chaos ultimately unites. The nine treasures’ essences mutually sustain each other. Hexagrams and medicine unite. Gold has three hundred and eighty-four *zhu*; each *zhu* corresponds to one *jin*, which is sixteen *liang*. When the essence of Gold transforms, the two qi become the elixir. The Azure Dragon receives the tally at this time. Within the divine chamber, its essence is refined. Gold and Fire interact, propelling the male yang’s emerald-green Water and the female yin’s ochre-yellow Gold. Yin and yang intermingle, uniting their essences and enveloping the primordial qi. The ten thousand images rely on emptiness to arise; through resonance and transformation, each has its being. The numinous traces of the many elixirs—none do not derive from this for attaining longevity.

Your servant Dao annotates: "Gold and Fire are true Lead." The two characters "Gold" and "Fire" are the essence of the sun and moon. Gold is the root of the moon; Fire is the root of the sun—both are born within Lead. Master Wei took Gold and Fire as the *Yi* and the *Yi* as the medicine. As the *Cantong Qi* states: "The *Yi* is the image." "When cinnabar is manifest, nothing is greater than [Gold and Fire]": cinnabar is the Metal liquid. The great elixir of the Metal liquid relies solely on the essence of the sun and moon to be achieved. "Gold is Lead; the moon is Water."

Mercury is cinnabar; Fire is the sun. Externally, Water and Fire ascend and descend; internally, Lead and Mercury intertwine and conjoin—beyond these, no other elixirs may enter. The transformations of Gold and cinnabar arise wholly from the essence of the sun and moon. As the *Cantong Qi* states: "When suspended images manifest their brightness, none are greater than the sun and moon." To speak of exhausting the subtle and mastering transformation: when Yang moves, Yin recedes. The ancients exhausted its subtleties and observed its waxing and waning, causing the qi of Yin and Yang to flow and rest in ceaseless circulation, completing the cycle of day and night. The *Cantong Qi* says: "Exhausting the numinous to know transformation: when Yang departs, Yin arrives."

At the culmination of primordial chaos, the nine treasures of essence mutually sustain one another. The qi of Kan and Li, Dragon and Tiger, intermingle within the numinous chamber, advancing and retreating with Water and Fire. At the outset, in the first palace of the Kan position, when the Fire number first stirs, essence and qi intermingle—this is before any transformation occurs. By the time of the Si position, when the Fire number reaches its apex, the Dragon generates Mercury and the Tiger generates Lead. The essence of Lead and Mercury gradually sprouts, while within the crucible, the qi of the sun and moon revolve externally, and the essence of Water and Fire unfolds and contracts internally. As the *Cantong Qi* states: "Like spokes converging at the hub, they revolve, emerging and entering, ever unfolding and contracting."

The hexagrams and the medicine unite: Gold comprises three hundred and eighty-four *zhu*. Each *zhu* corresponds to one *liang*, and sixteen *liang* make one *jin*. The hexagrams contain three hundred and eighty-four lines, matching the number of days in a celestial cycle, which together govern the entire fire-phase. Gold consists of three hundred and eighty-four *zhu*, and the Gold Mother totals one *jin*, which together govern the entire *jin* of the great elixir. The fire-phase and the Gold Mother thus perfectly correspond. As the *Cantong Qi* states: "The *Yi* has three hundred and eighty-four lines; according to the lines, the tally is drawn."

When the essence of Gold transforms, the Two Qi form the elixir. The Azure Dragon receives the tally: the Great Yin is the liquid of Metal-Tiger; the Great Yang is the fluid of Wood-Dragon. These transform into the true elixir. At the inception of the dark and new moon, when the Azure Dragon’s Fire Spirit assumes authority, the hexagram Zhen presides. As the *Cantong Qi* states: "From the dark of the moon to the dawn of the new, Zhen arrives to receive the tally."

At this very moment, within the numinous chamber, its essence is refined as Gold and Fire interact and propel one another—precisely when the Azure Dragon receives the tally and the fire is applied. Within the numinous chamber, the qi of Dragon and Tiger intertwine, the essence of Gold and Fire coalesce, and the numinous elixir is transformed. As the *Cantong Qi* states: "At this moment, Heaven and Earth conjoin their essence; the sun and moon mutually sustain one another."

The Azure Green Water of potent Yang and the Cinnabar Gold of latent Yin: potent Yang is Qian, Heaven.

The elder Yang is Qian, Heaven, the sun, and cinnabar. Its essence is called Azure Water, also known as "feminine mercury." The elder Yin is Kun, Earth, the moon, and lead. Its essence is called Yellow Gold, also known as "white gold." When the sun and moon conjoin within the crucible, the sun transforms into Azure Water and the moon transforms into Yellow Gold. Yellow Gold is true lead; Azure Water is true mercury. When lead and mercury merge as one, the elixir is formed. As the *Cantong Qi* states: "The potent Yang scatters Azure essence; the latent Yin gathers Yellow transformation."

When Yin and Yang intermingle, their essences unite, and primordial qi is enveloped—this refers to the qi of Yin and Yang, Dragon and Tiger, within the chaos, where Water and Fire interact and mutually transform, generating the fluid essence that becomes the foundation of the elixir. As the *Cantong Qi* states: "In the chaos of their union, the root and foundation are established."

All phenomena arise from emptiness, each responding to its own nature. All things in the world rely on primordial qi to take form, each fulfilling its nature and adhering to its shape. Within the crucible, the qi of Wood transforms into the Dragon, the qi of Metal into the Tiger, the qi of Fire into mercury, the qi of Water into lead, and the qi of Earth into harmony. The Five Qi all return to the Central Palace, nurturing the stem and calyx until spirit congeals into truth—each fulfilling its nature, solidifying into the real. As the *Cantong Qi* states: "Tending and nurturing the stem and calyx, spirit congeals to form the body."

The wondrous traces of all elixirs, the path to immortality, all derive from this. Among the twenty-four grades of the Golden Elixir, only this is the Great Elixir of Golden Fluid—the very Way by which one ascends to heaven in broad daylight. Clearly mirroring the images of Heaven and Earth, the sun and moon, the stars and constellations, the Five Phases, and the four seasons, all converge within the numinous chamber, transforming into the Golden Fluid of immortality. There is no path to longevity that does not proceed from this. As the *Cantong Qi* states: "All creatures, from the crawling to the soaring, none do not arise from this."

The *Chendao Shu* states: "Gold and Fire are indeed Lead and Fire."

Lead and Fire are indeed Water and Fire. When Gold and Fire interact, cinnabar is born within true Lead. What the ancients guarded most closely was the Fire Regimen alone. The Fire tally is one *jin*; the Mother tally is likewise one *jin*. When the Mother tally of one *jin* is divided, it becomes 384 *zhu*; when the Fire tally of one *jin* is divided, it becomes 384 *yao*, corresponding to the sixty-four hexagrams of a year. Thus, the tally of *Qian* is 216, and the tally of *Kun* is 144. Extending and expanding these, they reach 1,520, matching the tally of the myriad things and completing one cycle of Heaven and Earth. The ancients modeled their methods upon Heaven and Earth, aligning with the rise and fall of Yin and Yang, the ascent and descent of Water and Fire, the nature of Gold and Wood, and the embodiment of hardness and softness—thereby perfecting the transformations of the Great Dao. The tallies of *Qian* and *Kun*, each *yao* unfolding the Fire Regimen, reveal the subtleties of the Great Elixir’s numbers, manifesting the essence of Gold, Wood, Water, Fire, and Earth—these are the celestial signs. The refined supreme medicine and the movement of the Fire Regimen all accord with the numbers of these celestial signs. If one condenses the numbers of years, months, days, and hours into the twelve hours of a single day, advancing the Yang Fire and retreating the Yin tally to refine the Golden Fluid Divine Elixir, then the principle of creation can be immediately attained.

Thereupon, in *Chapter Twelve: The Mysterious Moisture and Radiant Luster*, the Primordial Sovereign of Mysterious Moisture and Radiant Luster begins to refine Mercury within the numinous chamber, which embraces the hollow and profound, where the Mysterious White gives birth to Lord Gold. Towering and majestic, he establishes the primordial beginning, as the Three and Five guard one another, their flying essence nourishing and moistening.

The *Chendao Annotation* states: "Here, the Primordial Sovereign of Mysterious Moisture and Radiant Luster begins to refine Mercury within the numinous chamber, which embraces the hollow and profound—this is when black Lead is transmuted into the essence of white Gold, its luster penetrating through to form the body of the numinous chamber, hollow within and an inch in diameter, to generate true Mercury. The Primordial Sovereign is the master who refines the Golden Elixir. As the *Baopuzi* states: 'The Primordial Sovereign herself said, “I too refined the Elixir and attained immortality.”' Fu Xi drew the Eight Trigrams, and Confucius expounded the *Yijing* images—both clarified these numbers of Heaven and Earth. As the *Cantong Qi* states: 'Thus, Confucius praised the Primal Chaos, where the virtue of *Qian* and *Kun* embraces the hollow and profound.' The Mysterious White gives birth to Lord Gold, towering and majestic, establishing the primordial beginning—this is the Mysterious generating white Gold. Thus, it can gather and nurture the essence of the sun and moon. Before the Yang Fire moves, both are concealed within white Gold, their forms unseen. Once Water and Fire circulate, the Gold Flower emerges from within white Gold—the Gold Flower is the harmonious *qi* of *wu* and *si*. When these two substances meet and interact, they generate the Elixir, which may truly be called towering and exalted. Investigating the ancient origins, this substance has always existed, enveloping Yin and Yang, never departing from the forms of the myriad things. The meaning of the *Guanju* lies in this: when Water and Fire interact, cinnabar and Mercury are born, and spirit and illumination emerge. Thus, it is the mother of the myriad things and the beginning of Yin and Yang. As the *Cantong Qi* states: 'Examining antiquity, when the Primordial Sovereign reigned, the *Guanju* established the primordial beginning.' The Three and Five guard one another, their flying essence moistening and nourishing the Fluid."

When Water, Fire, and Earth interact, the divine essence descends into the crucible. Thus, the ancient sages established the divine chamber—the *Jiji* crucible—where the forms of male and female unite, and the shapes of Dragon and Tiger merge. At first, form and substance remain undifferentiated, like primordial chaos. After the firing process, the essences of husband and wife intertwine, the passions of Dragon and Tiger harmonize, and the *yuan-nian* begins, bowing at its inception to ultimately refine the divine medicine.

As the *Cantong Qi* states: "When the marriage *qi* intertwines, the *yuan-nian* sprouts and flourishes." The *Chendao Shu* says: "The Primordial Sovereign, who refined the Elixir and attained immortality, was the ancestral master of antiquity. He modeled the numbers of Heaven and Earth, approximated the movements of the Sun and Moon, and with the crucible—symbolizing Qian and Kun—left a hollow space of slightly over an inch to house the numinous Mercury. This method mirrors the dynamic: when movement arises, Heaven’s *qi* descends, Earth’s *qi* responds, and the supreme essences of Heaven and Earth interact to generate the divine fluid." Truly towering and exalted, this is the most wondrous mystery.

Ancient immortals who attained the Dao feared that later generations would fail to grasp the true principle. Thus, they used cinnabar, Mercury, and various other medicinal substances to concoct the Great Elixir, unaware of the transformations of true Lead. Therefore, they employed symbolic language to enlighten disciples. If one resorts to miscellaneous methods, it is like entering the mountains to catch fish or a dragon seeking pheasants and hares in water—both are futile endeavors, a waste of effort.

**Chapter Fourteen: On the Intent of Concocting the Elixir**

Thus, the intent of concocting the Elixir—Heaven and Earth no longer speak of it. Cinnabar flows as mercury; Father is *wu* and *ji*, Mother is yellow gold. The bell and pitch-pipe return the two sixes; the Dipper’s handle establishes the three nines. The Crimson Youth plays with the Vermilion Bird, transforming into the Azure Dragon.

**Minister Dao’s Annotation:**
"Thus, the intent of concocting the Elixir—Heaven and Earth no longer speak of it" refers to the previous chapter, which expounded the intent of the Great Elixir, establishing the divine chamber and exhausting its wondrous principles. Thus, this chapter no longer repeats it.

"Cinnabar flows as mercury; Father is *wu* and *ji*, Mother is yellow gold": Cinnabar is the Sun; flowing mercury is the Sun’s spirit. *Wu* and *ji* are the Moon; yellow gold is the Moon’s essence. Cinnabar and *wu-ji* generate these two flavors—spirit and essence—to become the supreme medicine, hence they are called Father and Mother.

"The bell and pitch-pipe return the two sixes; the Dipper’s handle establishes the three nines": The two sixes refer to *zi, yin, chen, wu, shen, xu* as the six *lü* (pitch-pipes), and *chou, mao, si, wei, you, hai* as the six *lü* (harmonics). Moreover, *zi* is the Yellow Bell, and *wu* is the Jade Flute, which govern the twelve hours. The three nines also make twelve. The Dipper’s pointer determines the establishment: the first month establishes *yin*, the second month establishes *mao*, and so on through the twelve branches. As the *Canon of Pivoting Harmony* states: "Waxing and waning respond to the pitch-pipes; rising and falling rely on the Dipper’s pivot."

"The Crimson Youth plays with the Vermilion Bird, transforming into the Azure Dragon": The Crimson Youth is the Sun; the Vermilion Bird is Fire. Once Fire moves, the Sun generates mercury within the divine chamber, hence it is named the Azure Dragon. An ancient poem says: "The Five Agents’ inverted art—dragons emerge from Fire."

**Minister Dao’s Exegesis:**
The Supreme Ultimate generates the Two Modes; the Two Modes generate the Four Images; the Four Images generate the Eight Trigrams; the Eight Trigrams determine fortune and misfortune. Thus, *Qian* is Heaven—still, it is concentrated; in motion, it is straight. *Kun* is Earth—still, it contracts; in motion, it expands. Therefore, the classic states: "*Qian* and *Kun* are the body of Heaven and Earth; *Kan* and *Li* are the function of Heaven and Earth." The Dao gives birth to Heaven; Heaven gives birth to Earth; Earth gives birth to the myriad things. Thus, the movement and stillness of *Qian* and *Kun* give rise to the myriad things—this is Heaven.

The former is emptiness—yang, hardness, the sun, the father, Heaven. The latter is fullness—yin, softness, the moon, the mother, Earth. All below emptiness is Earth; all above fullness is Heaven. Thus, the interplay of emptiness and fullness gives rise to the six lines’ transformations. Therefore, *Qian* employs seven and nine, while *Kun* employs six and eight. The numbers of the Four Images correspond to the numbers of *Qian* and *Kun*, revealing the distinctions between old and young yin and yang. Four interacting with six yields twenty-four, thus forming the boundary of one old yin line; four interacting with eight yields thirty-two, forming the boundary of one young yin line; four interacting with seven yields twenty-eight, forming the boundary of one young yang line; four interacting with nine yields thirty-six, forming the boundary of one old yang line. These four boundaries constitute the completion numbers of *Qian* and *Kun*. The transformations of six and nine give rise to the generative numbers of the six lines.

Using old yin and old yang—nine and six—*Qian* and *Kun* alternate in transformation, while young yang and young yin—seven and eight—do not partake. *Qian* has six lines, and Earth receives three; *Kun* has six lines, and Heaven receives three. The two trigrams *Qian* and *Kun* form the transformative body of Heaven and Earth, perpetually merging as one and unfolding within the six voids, ascending and descending with the two qi of yin and yang, shifting and changing amid the six lines.

When *Qian* moves, it is straight and unyielding—yang fire blazes forth from below Earth, transforming *Kun*’s lower line into *Fu*. This is called "Initial Nine," the master of the six yang lines, where subtle yang has just arisen. The second transformation becomes *Lin*, where yang qi begins to flow; the third transformation brings yin and yang into communion, forming *Tai*, as the myriad things sprout, breaking through the earth. The fourth transformation becomes *Dazhuang*, where the myriad things flourish; the fifth transformation becomes *Guai*, where all plants reveal their essence. By the time of the "Upper Nine," it transforms into pure *Qian*—yang light radiates brilliantly, suffusing the southwest with lush vegetation. The yang light ascends above, the five colors gleam upon the head, and wells and springs freeze—this is the time of *Qian*’s full cycle.

When *Kun* moves, it expands without obstruction—yin stillness, solemn and serene, emerges from above Heaven, transforming *Qian*’s lower line into *Gou*. This is called "Initial Six," the master of the six yin lines, where subtle yin has just arisen. The second transformation becomes *Dun*, where yin qi begins to flow; the third transformation severs the communion of yin and yang, forming *Pi*, as the myriad things ripen, their fruits hanging low. The fourth transformation becomes *Guan*, where the myriad things wither; the fifth transformation becomes *Bo*, where all plants return to concealment. By the time of the "Upper Six," it transforms into pure *Kun*—yin essence, chilling and pervasive, blankets the southwest with withered, yellowed vegetation. Yin essence sinks below, the five colors hide within the roots, and wells and springs grow warm—this is the time of *Kun*’s full cycle.

Thus, the classic states: "The sun enters the earth, forming the image of congealed essence; after a second transformation, it becomes *Fu*, giving birth to the myriad things." From this, we know that the two bodies of *Qian* and *Kun* shift and move with the qi of yin and yang, ascending and descending within the six voids. One darkness, one brightness—cycling endlessly through day and night, the sun departs and the moon arrives, like a ring without end, beyond all reckoning. Only the singular, primal, harmonious qi brings about these transformations.

The ancient perfected ones understood the waxing and waning of Heaven and Earth, the expansion and contraction of yin and yang. Thus, they entrusted the *Yi*’s images to model *Qian* and *Kun*, aligning yin and yang with water and fire. They summoned the supreme harmony of Heaven and Earth, drew forth the pure essence of the sun and moon, and gathered them within the divine chamber. There, they transformed the liquid gold, transmuting the mortal frame into a sacred body. With merits complete and virtues fulfilled, their titles became "Perfected Ones." Who would not call them divine?

**Minister Dao’s Annotation on *Kun*’s Initial Transformation into *Zhen* (Chapter Fifteen):**
When *Kun*’s first transformation yields *Zhen*, on the third day, the moon emerges at *geng*, dividing east and west between *mao* and *you*. Dragon and tiger seek each other.

When *Kun*’s second transformation yields *Dui*, on the eighth day, the moon emerges at *ding*, its upper half like a balance. Half a catty of gold.

When *Kun*’s third transformation yields *Qian*, on the fifteenth day, the three yang lines are complete, illuminating the east at *jia*. Metal and water grow warm; the sun’s red marrow flows as mercury. The maiden plays with golden earrings; the moon waxes and naturally conjoins.

**Minister Dao’s Commentary:**
When *Kun*’s first transformation yields *Zhen*, on the third day, the moon emerges at *geng*: at midnight before the new moon, at the *zi* hour, the initial movement of yang fire begins. The sun and moon conjoin at the *Bi* and *Mao* constellations, where *Qian* intersects *Kun*’s lower line to form the *Zhen* trigram. *Zhen* governs affairs—one yang line arises below, so by the third day, the moon appears at the *geng* direction. As the *Cantong Qi* states: "On the third day, it emerges as brightness; *Zhen* receives *geng* in the west."

"Dividing east and west between *mao* and *you*, dragon and tiger seek each other": The east and west gates of the two eights are the directions of the sun and moon’s rising and setting. Once metal and water are properly positioned and the fire time has advanced five days, the qi of dragon and tiger yearn for each other, gathering within the crucible.

When *Kun*’s second transformation yields *Dui*, on the eighth day, the moon emerges at *ding*, its upper half like a balance: From the sixth to the eighth day, the upper half is complete. *Qian* intersects *Kun*’s second line to form the *Dui* trigram, which governs affairs—two yang lines arise in the middle, so the moon’s light achieves half-illumination, level as a cord, appearing at the *ding* direction. This illustrates the crucible where metal and fire are evenly matched. As the *Cantong Qi* states: "On the eighth day, *Dui* receives *ding*; the upper half is level as a cord."

When *Kun*’s third transformation yields *Qian*, on the fifteenth day, the three yang lines are complete, illuminating the east at *jia*: From the eleventh to the fifteenth day, *Qian* intersects *Kun*’s upper line to form the *Qian* trigram, which governs affairs—three yang lines arise above, so the moon’s light becomes full, appearing at the *jia* direction. This illustrates the crucible where the metal’s virtue is complete, having received the fire time. As the *Cantong Qi* states: "On the fifteenth day, the *Qian* body is replete, full at *jia* in the east."

"Metal and water grow warm; the sun’s red marrow flows as mercury; the maiden plays with golden earrings; the moon waxes and naturally conjoins": By this time, the divine elixir of liquid gold—with the sun’s essence now abundant—fills the divine chamber. The qi of metal and fire transforms into mercury, which, along with its mother, lingers in mutual affection, transmuting the golden body. Toad and hare essence intertwine, enveloping each other; their radiance illuminates the crucible. The maiden’s body naturally forms adornments, manifesting golden earrings—an analogy for the crucible where the metal qi gradually flourishes, transforming into the elixir. As the *Cantong Qi* states: "Toad and hare essence—sun and moon, peerless in brightness. The toad, observing the hexagram’s nodes, spits forth radiant light."

From the first to the fifteenth day of the great yin, the light fills; from the sixteenth day onward, it naturally conjoins. As the *Cantong Qi* states: "At seven and eight, the Dao is complete; bending and folding, it descends."

**Chapter Sixteen: The Sixteenfold Mutual Diminution**

The sixteenfold mutual diminution: when Qian’s first line is diminished, it forms Feng, and the bright moon appears at Xin. When Qian’s second line is diminished, it forms Gen, and at twenty-three, the lower half-measure of water weighs half a catty, the moon emerging in the south at Bing. When Qian’s third line is diminished, it forms Kun, and on the thirtieth day, in the northeast, it loses its brightness, the moon setting at Yi-earth. As Kun and Yi-moon darken, earth, water, and metal are about to transform. Kun gives birth to Zhen the Dragon.

Minister Dao’s annotation states: "The sixteenfold mutual diminution—when Qian’s first line is diminished to form Feng, and the bright moon appears at Xin—refers to the period after the sixteenth day, when Kun interchanges with Qian’s lower line to form the Feng hexagram. Feng governs affairs: one yin line arises below as yang fire begins its retreat and yin tally first emerges. At dawn, the moon appears in the Xin direction, just as when yang fire first advances, the moon is three days old.
