As the *Cantong Qi* states: 'At sixteenfold reception, Feng governs; Xin appears at dawn.'

When Qian’s second line is diminished to form Gen, at twenty-three, the lower half-measure of water weighs half a catty, and the moon emerges in the south at Bing. From the sixteenth day, as yin tally retreats to the twenty-third, Kun interchanges with Qian’s middle line to form the Gen hexagram. Gen governs affairs: two yin lines arise in the center, and the moon appears in the Bing direction, again corresponding to the upper half-measure. This signifies that within the crucible, metal and water are evenly balanced. As the *Cantong Qi* states: 'Gen aligns with Bing in the south; the lower half-measure at twenty-three.'

When Qian’s third line is diminished to form Kun, on the thirtieth day, in the northeast, it loses its brightness, the moon setting at Yi-earth. From the twenty-sixth to the twenty-eighth day, Kun interchanges with Qian’s upper line to form the Kun hexagram. Kun governs affairs: three yin lines arise above, and the moon’s light nears its end, appearing in the Yi direction. Reaching the northeast, yang light is entirely spent—this is called the loss of brightness. As the *Cantong Qi* states: 'Kun and Yi, on the thirtieth day, in the east, lose their brightness.'

When Kun and Yi-moon darken, earth, wood, and metal are about to transform, and Kun gives birth to Zhen the Dragon. From the twenty-eighth to the thirtieth day, yin tally is exhausted, and the qi of yin and yang each come to rest. Earth, metal, and water combine into a liquid; the six yang qi do not unite with the moon. The body of Great Yin turns wholly dark, traversing the northeast and passing over Mao and Bi, where sun and moon conjoin. Water and fire are again applied, returning to their origin, taking Fu as the first hexagram. Kun transforms into Zhen, which pertains to wood and resides in the east—hence it is called the Dragon. Moreover, yang fire is the Dragon. As the *Cantong Qi* states: 'When the node is exhausted, they alternate; with the transformation of the body, the Dragon is reborn.'

Minister Dao’s commentary states: From Zi to Si, yang fire advances for six hours, governed by Zhen, Dui, and Qian—this is the movement of Great Yin, the image of metal liquid. Fu, Lin, Tai, Da Zhuang, and Guai, governed by Qian, are the movement of Great Yang, the image of yang fire. From Wu to Hai, yin tally retreats for six hours, governed by Feng, Gen, and Kun—this is the movement of Great Yin, the image of metal liquid. Gou, Dun, Pi, Guan, Bo, and Kun are the movement of Great Yin, the image of yin tally. The transformations of metal and water within the crucible are governed by twelve lines and twelve hours; the movements of the moon’s radiance in the heavens are governed by six hexagrams and twelve hours. The *Cantong Qi* speaks of this in great detail, yet people fail to perceive it clearly.

Those who cultivate the Dao, desiring to refine this Great Elixir, must understand astronomy above, geography below, and human nature within. Only then can they adapt to the transformations of creation, grasp yin and yang in hand, revolve the sun and moon within the furnace, and breed the Dragon and Tiger. They unite Qian and Kun within the chamber, nurturing essence and fluids. The Metal Mother labors without exhaustion; the Wood Father achieves success with ease. The metal liquid transforms, cinnabar mercury takes form, the nine revolutions conclude, and yang light changes—this is the Yellow Chariot, named the Dust of the Bright Window. Not only does it transmute cinnabar into gold, but when ingested, it equals heaven in longevity. The marvels of transformation cannot be surpassed.

**Chapter Seventeen: Qian and Kun Encompass Beginning and End**

Qian and Kun encompass beginning and end—thus it is said: Zhen the Dragon. As above, over thirty days, Kun gives birth to Zhen, Dui, and Qian; Qian gives birth to Feng, Gen, and Kun. The eight hexagrams are arrayed, their luminous movements shifting without losing the center.

Minister Dao’s annotation states: Qian and Kun encompass beginning and end—thus it is said: Zhen the Dragon. Qian and Kun are the father and mother of all hexagrams. The two hexagrams interweave to form the eight hexagrams: Qian first interchanges with Kun’s lower line to form Zhen, marking the new moon at the first day’s midnight, the Zi hour, the beginning of yang fire’s arising. Kun then interchanges with Qian’s lower line to form Feng, beginning at the sixteenth day’s midnight, the Zi hour, the start of yin tally’s arising. As the *Cantong Qi* states: 'Ren and Gui pair with Jia and Yi; Qian and Kun encompass beginning and end.'

As above, over thirty days, Kun gives birth to Zhen, Dui, and Qian: Kun gives birth to Zhen, governing the first five days as the direct tally; next, it gives birth to Dui, governing the middle five days as the direct tally; then, it gives birth to Qian, governing the last five days as the direct tally. Great Yang stands for fifteen days, reaching fullness at Jia above, and the metal liquid in the crucible also flourishes, increasing in accord with the hexagrams.

Qian gives birth to Feng, governing the first five days as the direct tally; next, it gives birth to Gen, governing the middle five days as the direct tally; then, it gives birth to Kun, governing the last five days as the direct tally. Great Yin stands for fifteen days, its light exhausted in the northeast, the Gen region, and the metal liquid in the crucible also reaches fullness, forming in accord with the hexagrams. Qian and Kun mutually generate and extinguish over thirty days, the cycle of one month. As the *Cantong Qi* states: 'Seven and eight make fifteen; nine and six also correspond. The four together make thirty—yang qi seeks extinction and concealment.'

The eight hexagrams are arrayed, their luminous movements shifting without losing the center. As above, the eight hexagrams are arrayed within one month’s thirty days, moving yang fire and yin tally, each converging within the divine chamber to transform the Great Elixir and metal liquid. As the *Cantong Qi* states: 'The eight hexagrams are arrayed; their luminous movements shift without losing the center.'

Minister Dao’s commentary states: The human body also embodies heaven and earth. Within it, the ascent and descent of yin and yang likewise correspond to the transformations of creation. Yet, through the six desires and seven emotions, they are expressed externally, while essence and qi are depleted internally. All day long, one rushes about heedlessly, unaware of reflection. If one can know this Dao, follow yin and yang, and guard simplicity with tranquility, then heaven and earth will externally interact while the body internally harmonizes. Each will respond to its ascent and descent. With minimal thought and no harm, one will naturally prolong life. How much more so when establishing the furnace and crucible, modeling heaven and earth, summoning the essence of sun and moon, and drawing the harmonious qi of yin and yang to refine the divine medicine and ingest it—how could one not become an immortal?

To craft the golden liquor, one must first understand the numerical degrees traversed by Qian and Kun in the eight trigrams over the course of a month—thirty days in total. The sun moves one degree per day, while the moon moves thirteen degrees. Though both complete one cycle in a month, they converge in the same palace, known as the new moon. The sun travels thirty degrees, and the moon three hundred ninety-five degrees, passing through twelve months before reuniting with the sun above the Dipper mansion on the winter solstice.

Thus, the perfected one uses the degrees of the sun and moon’s movement as the period for firing in one month: the first fifteen days are governed by Zhen, Dui, and Qian, while the latter fifteen are governed by Xun, Gen, and Kun. Kan and Li hold their positions, with yang fire and yin tally advancing or retreating according to the time, all in accordance with the symbolic lines of the trigrams.

**Chapter Eighteen: Regulating the Fire for Sixty Days**
Regulating the fire for sixty days brings about transformations that serve as proof. The divine chamber takes on a form resembling a chicken’s egg, with the Five Peaks standing in concealment and the cavern’s gate possessing a pivot and bolt.

Minister Dao’s annotation: "Regulating the fire for sixty days brings about transformations that serve as proof" refers to the original essence within the crucible, whose state is difficult to observe. After completing one month’s cycle and opening the crucible, one may find golden blossoms descending or jade liquid congealing slowly—these are signs of excess or deficiency in yin tally and yang fire. Thus, another month of firing is required to complete the alchemical process.

Therefore, as the original essence in the crucible receives the externally applied tally-fire, each transformation is subtle and hard to perceive. Yet by observing the twelve time-periods and the firing conditions of the trigrams, one can discern its movements, whether sinking or floating. As the *Cantong Qi* states: "The original essence is subtle and hard to perceive; one infers its effects by observing the tally’s signs."

"The divine chamber takes on a form resembling a chicken’s egg" means that the ancient perfected ones, gazing up at the celestial patterns and examining the earth’s principles, modeled the divine chamber after Heaven and Earth, shaping it like a chicken’s egg. Within its hollow center, a space of slightly over an inch is reserved for the numinous mercury. As the *Cantong Qi* says: "When dwelling, observe its image and approximate its form."

"The Five Peaks stand in concealment, and the cavern’s gate possesses a pivot and bolt" describes how the sacred mountains on earth are divided into the Five Peaks, all interconnected in hidden ways. The ancients established markers to serve as models, constructing altars, furnaces, crucibles, and stoves in accordance with the mysterious method, ensuring their intricate connections allowed the fire’s qi to circulate without obstruction. If the firing conditions scatter externally, fortune or misfortune arises internally. As the *Cantong Qi* states: "Erect markers to serve as standards; observe the omens to determine fortune or misfortune."

Minister Dao’s commentary: Before Heaven and Earth separated, their form resembled a chicken’s egg. After their separation, the yang fire ascended, and the light, pure qi congealed to form Heaven, while the yin water sank, and the heavy, turbid qi congealed to form Earth—this is called the fixed positions of Heaven and Earth. The divine chamber consists of an upper cauldron as Heaven and a lower cauldron as Earth, their two halves joined to resemble a chicken’s egg. Within its hollow center, slightly over an inch of space is called the fixed position of the divine chamber. When Heaven and Earth interact, fire is born within water and ascends, while water is born within fire and descends, converging within the true earth to produce medicinal substances. Similarly, in the divine chamber, fire arises from Kan and water descends from Li, converging within Wu and Ji to generate the numinous mercury—such profound and wondrous secrets can be known.

**Chapter Nineteen: The Initial Firing is Gentle and Subtle**
The initial firing is gentle and subtle, like the movement of a line in the trigrams. Above, it bears the essence of yellow gold; below, it carries the primordial Kun. Its form is harmonious, flowing with pure fluid, and when examined, it unites the Three Powers. Qian moves in response to the Three Luminaries, while Kun remains still, containing yang qi.

Minister Dao’s annotation: "The initial firing is gentle and subtle, like the movement of a line in the trigrams" means that when initiating the divine elixir’s firing, one must follow the symbolic lines of the trigrams and align with the twelve months’ waxing and waning. For instance, the hexagram *Fu* (Return), representing the winter solstice, governs the season when the lowest line transforms into yang, corresponding to the *zi* hour.

At this time, the firing is not yet forceful but merely warm—this is called "soft fire," corresponding to the initial generation of the single yang line in *Fu*. As the *Cantong Qi* states: "Issue commands in accordance with the seasons; do not miss the time when the lines move."

"Above, it bears the essence of yellow gold; below, it carries the primordial Kun" refers to yellow gold as Qian Heaven, the upper cauldron, and Kun as Kun Earth, the lower cauldron. The two cauldrons combine to form the divine chamber. As the *Cantong Qi* says: "Above, examine the patterns of the *He Tu*; below, recount the earth’s forms."

"Its form is harmonious, flowing with pure fluid, and when examined, it unites the Three Powers" means that once the divine chamber is positioned, the pure fluid and numinous mercury are generated within it. The numinous center of the middle palace also symbolizes the human heart-mind’s dwelling. Thus, when Heaven, Earth, and Humanity are complete, the myriad things are named, and the Five Agents are activated. As the *Cantong Qi* states: "Examine the center in relation to the human heart, uniting the Three Powers."

"Qian moves in response to the Three Luminaries; Kun remains still, containing yang qi" refers to Qian as Heaven, the sun, and fire.

Within the empty vessel, as Qian’s primordial movement stirs, the essence of water and fire arises, producing the golden fluid. Kun is Earth, the moon, and water. As Kun’s primordial stillness abides, the essence of moon, water, and metal harmonizes with the flowing pearl of great yang, enclosing it to prevent its flight. As the *Cantong Qi* states: "In motion, it follows the changes of the hexagrams; in stillness, it adheres to the judgments of the *tuan*. When Qian and Kun are put into practice, how can one not proceed with utmost care?"

The *Chendao Shu* says: The sun occupies the position of *Li*, dwelling in the south amid *Bing* and *Ding*—the true seat of fire. The sun also contains fire, and fire transforms its body to become mercury; thus, it is said that mercury is born from the sun. Mercury is yang, called the yang spirit. The *Li* hexagram consists of two yang lines and one yin line, with *Si* earth as its spirit, and it is also the middle daughter of Kun. The sun employs *Si* earth as its light—*Si* being a yin position—so its image corresponds to the *Li* hexagram. Moreover, the sun’s light contains a dark hue, which, shifting from blue to red, becomes cinnabar.

The moon belongs to the position of *Kan*, residing in the north amid *Ren* and *Gui*—the true seat of water. The moon also contains water and transforms its body to become metal; thus, it is said that metal is born from the moon. Metal is yin, called the yin soul. The *Kan* hexagram consists of two yin lines and one yang line, with *Wu* earth as its spirit, and it is also the middle son of Qian. The moon employs *Wu* earth as its essence—*Wu* earth being a yang position—so its image corresponds to the *Kan* hexagram. Moreover, the moon’s essence contains a pale hue, which, shifting from white to black, becomes black lead.

Mercury, containing the qi of *Li*, aligns with the position of the yin line. This mercury is not the common quicksilver or cinnabar of the world but originates within great yang; *Li* names it the water spirit, calling it true mercury. Lead, containing the qi of *Kan*, aligns with the position of the yang line. This lead is not the salt lead of Jiazhou or that found among rocks but originates within great yin; *Kan* names it white metal, calling it true lead.

Lead divides into two, forming the two poles of the divine chamber. Mercury arises from the one, the single qi of the dark fluid. Together, they image the Three Powers as Heaven, Earth, and Humanity.

*Guwen Longhu Jing Zhushu*, Middle Scroll
*Imperially Commissioned Siku Quanshu*
*Guwen Longhu Jing Zhushu*, Lower Scroll
By Wang Dao of the Song Dynasty
Chapter Twenty: "The Divine Chamber’s Prior Practice"

The Divine Chamber’s Prior Practice: Only after first applying the golden elixir can completion be firm. The qi of refinement and transformation envelops and congeals in flight; the numinous portal opens and closes, the abode of the subtle and imperceptible, the cavern of creation and transformation.

Minister Dao’s Annotation: "Only after first applying the golden elixir can completion be firm" means that once the Divine Chamber is established and its method attained, the golden liquid necessarily follows the principle of completion. "Can it not be firm? The qi of refinement and transformation envelops and congeals in flight" signifies that the adept refining the elixir must first firmly prepare the crucible and vessel, ensuring the numinous mercury within solidifies and congeals without escaping, only then can the elixir be formed. "The numinous portal opens and closes, the abode of the subtle and imperceptible, the cavern of creation and transformation" describes how the Divine Chamber possesses upper and lower cauldrons: when open, they are two; when closed, they are one. Within, the void space allows water and fire to interact, and the numinous substance is born. Thus, it is called the subtle and imperceptible. White metal becomes the elixir and generates mercury, termed the golden liquid. This is the treasury and cavern of the elixir.

Minister Dao’s Exegesis: The water of the north generates and completes white metal, calling it true lead, the essence of utmost yin. It contains the harmonious yang, following the qi of primordial chaos as it divides and returns each to its original unity. The perfected of antiquity modeled the Dao of Heaven and Earth’s generation and completion, returning the harmonious yang qi to true lead, containing its natural function to refine the great medicine. This is the qi of true origin, not something worldly substances can achieve. If the methods of cultivation and refinement are correct and the system reasonable, how can one fail to complete the great elixir? The dragon and tiger, both born within lead, through the ascent and descent of water and fire, cause metal and wood to interact in the abode of the subtle and imperceptible. The cavern of creation and transformation guards the waxing and waning of the sun and moon. White metal, as mother, envelops the multitude of spirits to produce the supreme treasure.

Chapter Twenty-One: "Yang Qi Arises in Kun"
Yang qi arises in Kun; the sundial points to the southern extreme. The five stars form a pearl string; the sun and moon unite as jade discs. Golden sand adheres to its division, breathing in resonance.

Minister Dao’s Annotation: "Yang qi arises in Kun; the sundial points to the southern extreme" refers to the end of the tenth month, when the pure Kun hexagram concludes, and the beginning of the eleventh month, the midnight hour of the zi period, when the Kun hexagram’s lower line generates one yang line, forming the Fu hexagram—this is the time when yang fire is born. Progressing through chou, yin, and reaching si, yang qi reaches its extreme in the south, then yin arises at wu. "The five stars form a pearl string; the sun and moon unite as jade discs" describes how the five stars traverse the celestial circuit like a string of pearls, with varying speeds, stations, retrogradations, and progressions. The sun and moon’s degrees converge once a month in union, their jade-disc conjunction aligning with the five stars to mutually verify the year’s use of metal and fire. "Golden sand adheres to its division, breathing in resonance" means golden sand is the essence of the sun and moon. As water and fire ascend and descend, inhaling and exhaling, golden sand in the crucible rises and sinks, following the rhythm of breath to resonate with the externally applied fire.

Minister Dao’s Exegesis: True lead is the mother, Kun, the body of great yin, perpetually dark. Only upon encountering yang fire does it take form. Once formed, it traverses the sixty-four hexagrams and three hundred eighty-four lines, transforming endlessly, all following the numerical movements of the sun, moon, and five stars. If one uses miscellaneous substances for the elixir, how can it follow the yin-yang and four seasons to generate? As the *Cantong Qi* states: "The sun contains the essence of the five phases; the moon receives the discipline of the six pitch-pipes."

Chapter Twenty-Two: "The Canopy of Flowers Descends"
The canopy of flowers descends; the Three Terraces assist below. They govern the records and administrations, ensuring firmness and scrutinizing competence.

Minister Dao’s Annotation: "The canopy of flowers descends; the Three Terraces assist below, governing the records and administrations, ensuring firmness and scrutinizing competence" describes how the canopy of flowers, sixteen stars shaped like a cover, resides in the Purple Tenuity Palace, corresponding to the imperial throne. The Three Terraces, six stars outside the Purple Tenuity Palace, regulate the harmony of yin and yang and the governance of the myriad things, likened to water and fire residing in the golden crucible above and below. If harmony and regulation are proper, the numinous essence descends within. The Three Terraces govern the records and administrations, leading the hundred officials, akin to the prime minister’s duty, also called Wenchang. If the five stars shrink or expand improperly, the sun and moon advance or retreat irregularly, the four seasons fail to respond, and wind and rain arrive untimely, causing the myriad things not to grow—this is like the adept refining the elixir who, if their operations are irregular, causes the crucible to dry or overflow, leading to constant anomalies and the failure of the elixir. If all seasonal nodes are mastered as if turning in the palm, the crucible is firmly sealed without mishap. If even one aspect is mismanaged, the competence of the fire’s application is scrutinized. As the *Cantong Qi* states: "Wenchang governs the records; the terraces and assistants, the hundred officials and offices, each oversee their respective domains."

Minister Dao’s Exegesis: Many in the world study the Dao, yet those who grasp its wondrous principles are one in ten thousand. Some feign its name to pursue illicit gain; some falsely claim to transmute yellow and white, engaging in alchemical deceptions. Others recklessly point to ancient texts, refining the five metals and eight minerals in hopes of fortuitously obtaining the great medicine, wasting years and exhausting spirit, yet achieving nothing. The foolish compound their errors; the wise diminish their conduct. They cling to delusion until death, never repenting, bewildered and entangled without end. Some lose their professions, squander their wealth, forfeit parental care, sever spousal love, drifting in hunger and cold—such cases span generations. Little do they know that the golden mother and great medicine are not crafted from common lead or mercury but are the spirit of Heaven and Earth, the souls of the sun and moon. How can one fail to enter its domain?

Chapter Twenty-Three: "Fire Refines the Central Palace Earth"
Fire refines the central palace earth; metal enters the northern water. Water, earth, and metal—three substances transform over sixty days, the essentials of natural generation and decay. If the fire count is excessive or the weights deviate, mercury may become unstable, dwelling apart or resisting harmony. Hard and soft contend, failing to interpenetrate—this is not fire’s fault but earth’s reprimand.

Minister Dao’s Annotation: "Fire refines the central palace earth; metal enters the northern water" means fire is the sun, metal the moon. The two natures of metal and fire follow the qi of the five phases and six pitch-pipes to generate. Thus, fire generates earth, and metal generates water, each exhaling its essence to become the divine medicine. As the *Cantong Qi* states: "The sun contains the essence of the five phases; the moon receives the discipline of the six pitch-pipes." "Water, earth, and metal—three substances transform over sixty days" describes how the central palace contains only the golden mother, while water and earth, two substances, harmonize through the fire’s timing. If in one month the fire’s timing does not align with the mother’s count, another month of firing is required. As the *Cantong Qi* states: "Five times six makes thirty degrees; once completed, it begins anew." "The essentials of natural generation and decay" mean the golden liquid divine elixir entirely depends on the fire’s timing. Fire is the medicine’s parent; the medicine is fire’s progeny, naturally generated by the qi of Heaven and Earth.

If the fire’s power is evenly maintained, it generates golden mercury; if the fire’s power is misaligned, it instead leads to dispersion and loss, with unpredictable preservation or decay—this must be measured within sixty days to determine its beginning and end. As the *Cantong Qi* states: "To trace the origin and grasp the end, to discern the threads of preservation and decay."

If the fire’s count is excessive or the weights deviate, when the yang fire’s count is too great, the spirit and qi are harmed, causing the golden mercury to overflow and overfill the crucible, violating the proper measure. As the *Cantong Qi* states: "If the lord grows arrogant and overbearing, he strays from the Dao."

If the mercury is unstable, now dwelling together, now apart, this mercury is the golden liquid. Should the fire’s count err, the mercury within the crucible chamber will follow the fire’s fluctuations, failing to adhere to the proper path—thus it may unite or separate unpredictably. As the *Cantong Qi* states: "If the minister is treacherous and perverse, his conduct does not follow the proper track."

When hardness and softness contend without mutual penetration, the fault does not lie with the fire but is imputed to the earth. If the golden sand does not arise according to measure, hardness and softness fail to interpenetrate—not solely the fire’s error, but also because the central palace’s golden mother is impure, her essence and qi slightly lost. Thus, the fault is not ascribed to fire but to earth. As the *Cantong Qi* states: "When the waxing and waning of the moon deviate, misfortune arises; the enforcer of the law reproaches and interrogates, blaming the ruler."

The *Minister’s Dao* commentary states: Those who refine the elixir must understand the movements of the sun and moon, comprehend the principles of yin and yang’s ascent and descent, grasp the withdrawal and addition of the fire’s timing, and distinguish the authenticity of medicinal substances—only then can success be assured. This truly depends on the person who regulates the fire’s timing. If one is ignorant of these matters and enforces the method inconsistently, blaming the inadequacy of the oral transmission or criticizing the master’s teachings without self-realization—those who cherish the Dao should take heed of this.

**Chapter Twenty-Four: Earth Ruling the Central Palace**

Earth rules the central palace, enveloping the four directions; the three luminaries align to bring great peace. The five viscera are internally nourished, the four limbs harmonized; water dries, fire extinguishes, inner radiance is contained, and brilliance shines within. Metal and wood mutually refine, their flow sealed; by regulating water and warming fire, all transform, and the Dao may be sought nearby.

The *Minister’s Dao* commentary states: "Earth rules the central palace, enveloping the four directions"—earth is wu and ji, the mother. The mother resides in the central palace, summoning the harmonious qi of the four directions into the divine chamber to transform into the golden liquid. As the *Cantong Qi* states: "The pole star stands at the center, like the golden mother, who can leisurely embrace all subjects." Thus it says: "The pole star stands at the center, leisurely governing below."

"The three luminaries align to bring great peace"—the three luminaries are the sun, moon, and stars. If the three luminaries advance and retreat without error above, the world below attains great peace, commands are executed, prohibitions upheld, and the state suffers no disorder. The internal operation of the elixir also possesses three luminaries: the yang fire, yin water, and golden embryo, which symbolize the sun, moon, and stars. Thus, the external operation also has three luminaries, distributed within the moving and static lines, the moments and breaths, the yin and yang symbols, and the fire’s timing. If the regulation of the symbols is correct, there will be no harm of escape—like governing a state to achieve great peace. As the *Cantong Qi* states: "The bright hall enacts governance; the state suffers no harm—this is the Dao."

"The five viscera are internally nourished, the four limbs harmonized"—if the regulation of the symbolic fire fully accords with the celestial degrees, then within the crucible chamber, the true person’s body, the five viscera and four limbs are harmonized and at peace, tranquil and empty, serene and desireless, attaining the center—thus there is no risk of premature death. As the *Cantong Qi* states: "Internally, one nurtures oneself in stillness and emptiness."

"Water dries, fire extinguishes, inner radiance is contained"—when refining the great elixir, at the *si* hour, water dries; at the *hai* hour, fire extinguishes. By these two hours, the essence and qi of metal and fire each attain their proper state, their brilliance pervading the chamber, illuminating the true person’s body. As the *Cantong Qi* states: "Tracing the origin to its brightness, it illuminates the body within."

"Metal and wood mutually refine, their flow sealed"—the qi of dragon and tiger intermingle, the natures of metal and wood harmonize. Metal comes to restrain wood; wood, though restrained by metal, becomes radiant, causing its brilliance to be sealed within the crucible, the numinous root enclosed in the chamber—all nurtured and transformed by the golden mother. The golden mother’s transformations are unfathomable; this subtlety is difficult to convey without oral transmission. As the *Cantong Qi* states: "Seal its opening, fortify the numinous root."

"By regulating fire and warming water, all transform, and the Dao may be sought nearby"—the golden mother within the crucible gathers the qi of the three luminaries and the essence of the sun and moon, giving birth to the sacred embryo, whose form is inscrutable. The numinous mercury of the child and root resides in the divine chamber, hidden and difficult to perceive. If the fire does not lose its timing and water does not lose its measure, water and fire both follow the Dao, ascending and descending according to principle, conforming to the celestial mechanism and the model of the law—then the golden mercury will naturally cherish the dragon and tiger’s natures, their essences intermingling. Seeking its transformations by analogy, the principle of the Dao becomes visible. As the *Cantong Qi* states: "The three luminaries sink into obscurity; by warming and nurturing, the child-pearl is unseen—nearby and easily sought."

The *Minister’s Dao* commentary states: Human principles can be inferred by analogy. Before the essence of the three luminaries appears and the qi of the four images separates, the mysterious yellow is in chaos, clear and turbid undivided, the qi of true lead mixed within. Once the clear is used for heaven and the turbid for earth, the harmony of yin and yang forms humanity—thus the three powers are established. The qi of true lead resides in the center, at the position of wu and ji, becoming the mother of the divine medicine, enveloping the qi of metal, wood, water, and fire to congeal into the golden liquid. Among the five phases, metal comes to restrain wood; within wood is fire, which counter-restrains metal. Metal and fire mutually restrain, refining each other. Water comes to restrain fire; within fire is earth, which counter-restrains water. Water and earth mutually pair, transforming each other—this principle of mutual generation and restraint lies in oral transmission and cannot be written. If sought through the celestial Dao, it is merely a single taste of primordial harmony.

**Chapter Twenty-Five: Water and Earth Alone Pairing**

Water and earth alone pair; kingfishers give birth amidst auspicious clouds. The yellow and black blend the primordial essence; purple flowers unfold in the great yang. Water alone can generate the myriad things—only the sage knows this.

The *Minister’s Dao* commentary states: "Water and earth alone pair; kingfishers give birth amidst auspicious clouds"—water is the mysterious water, earth is the golden mother. When the fire of the great yang unites with the golden mother, within the divine chamber, the essence of wood transforms into qi, giving rise to auspicious clouds, gradually congealing into flowing pearls that moisten the elixir palace to transform into the golden liquid. As the *Cantong Qi* states: "The yellow center gradually opens; the principle moistens and reaches the skin."

The blending of yellow and black forms the primordial essence; purple flowers unfold in the great yang—yellow and black are also water and earth. When the qi of water and earth restrain each other, they generate the primordial essence of the great yang. If one harmonizes with the celestial patterns, comprehending their beginning and end to grasp their subtle principle, then the primordial essence of the great yang gradually manifests between existence and non-existence, giving rise to the *yinqie* and unfolding purple flowers, while the yellow liquid surges and swirls—this is the divine medicine before it solidifies. As the *Cantong Qi* states: "When the beginning is correct, the end is cultivated; the stem is established, and the fruit may be held."

That water alone can generate the myriad things, and only the sage knows this—water is the first of the numbers, the mysterious heaven generates water, which resides in the north. Within water, metal is born, and metal in turn generates water. The sage, knowing this, models its image to refine the divine elixir, which the foolish and ignorant cannot fathom. As the *Cantong Qi* states: "The One is used to conceal it; the world does not know."

The *Minister’s Dao* commentary states: The Qian and Kun, the two bodies, envelop the mysterious image. Heaven’s One generates water, called mysterious water; earth’s Five generates soil, called true earth. When water and earth unite, they give birth to the myriad things. The sage, understanding this transformation, models heaven and earth to establish the divine chamber, aligning with yin and yang to employ water and fire. Following the patterns of the hexagrams, traversing the four seasons, the primordial essence is born, and the divine mercury emerges.

**Chapter Twenty-Six: The Virtue of Metal Prefers White**
The virtue of metal prefers white; refining lead seeks the yellow hue. Through resonance, it generates within the central palace, where yellow gold melts without flying, and scorched earth gives rise to clouds of smoke.

The *Minister’s Dao* commentary states: "The virtue of metal prefers white; refining lead seeks the yellow hue"—refining lead produces white metal, and white metal forms the divine chamber. Within the divine chamber lies metal-water, which, transformed by fire, changes its color to yellow, called the Yellow Chariot. As the *Cantong Qi* states: "Below lies the qi of the great yang, steaming for a moment; first it liquefies, then congeals, named the Yellow Chariot."

"Through resonance, it generates within the central palace, where yellow gold melts without flying, and scorched earth gives rise to clouds of smoke"—as the golden liquid is about to form, it congeals with water and fire within the vessel. Originating from metal, it transforms into liquid, resonating and coalescing in the central palace, so the liquid of yellow gold naturally does not escape. Fire scorches the golden essence, and the pure qi becomes clear and luminous, sometimes manifesting as light smoke or thin mist within the crucible chamber, its transformations boundless. It may resemble stalactites hanging inverted, or interlocking canine teeth; it may take the form of the sun and moon, revealing both hun and po, or transform into the shapes of dragons and tigers, where metal and water unite, and spirits manifest in myriad forms beyond description. If one were to use the five metals, eight stones, or various other杂 substances to create this, how could such divine transformations be attained?

The *Minister’s Dao* commentary states: Among all things in the world, only yellow gold cannot be destroyed. Since the beginning of creation, only the body of metal remains undiminished. Thus, the mother of yellow gold is called true lead. True lead is the One of pre-heaven; before the separation of chaos, the qi of lead resided within it. When heaven and earth took form, the body of lead also appeared. If the myriad things lacked the qi of lead, they could not achieve their wondrous functions. Therefore, the qi of true lead is omnipresent.

Moreover, black metal generates white metal, white metal generates yellow metal, and yellow metal generates the supreme medicine. If one ingests it, one’s lifespan aligns with heaven and earth, and one’s body merges with the Dao. Thus, the essence of metal’s virtue is the master of all medicines and the origin of the myriad things.

**Chapter Twenty-Seven: Existence and Non-Existence Mutually Restrain**
Existence and non-existence mutually restrain; above dwells the Green Dragon, residing in the two non-existences’ origin. The One’s numinous transformation is wondrous and difficult to perceive.

The *Minister’s Dao* commentary states: "Existence and non-existence mutually restrain; above dwells the Green Dragon"—existence refers to white metal, and non-existence refers to the qi of fire. Thus, existence and non-existence interact, mutually restraining and uniting metal and water to generate the numinous mercury within the central palace. Mercury is the Green Dragon. As the *Cantong Qi* states: "When the upper is closed, it is called existence; when the lower is closed, it is called non-existence. Non-existence serves to uphold the upper, where the divine power resides."

"The two non-existences’ origin, the One’s numinous transformation is wondrous and difficult to perceive"—the two non-existences are the qi of yin and yang, the hun and po of the sun and moon. The One’s existence is also the divine embryo. Within the divine embryo, there are no杂 substances, only an empty vessel. Through the qi of water and fire, it draws the essence of the sun and moon, uniting the purest of yin and yang to enter the divine embryo. The numinous transformation of the golden liquid is beyond perception. Above and below the divine chamber, the qi of water and fire, through the nurturing of the metal mother, mutually require each other to generate. As the *Cantong Qi* states: "These two apertures follow the method; the qi of metal also mutually requires this."

The *Minister’s Dao* commentary states: The golden liquid, named the Yellow Chariot, is the name of the ninefold transmutation. The ancients, when ingesting the elixir, first purified themselves through fasting and inner clarity, then consumed the outer elixir, so that inner and outer were both perfected. The true qi steamed and suffused the four limbs, reversing aging to return to youth, becoming a body of pure yang, and attaining a lifespan equal to heaven.

**Chapter Twenty-Eight: Refining Silver from Lead**
Refining silver from lead, the divine substance generates itself. Silver is the essence of metal; lead envelops the northern numen. Water is the pivot of the Dao, its number named the One, the beginning of yin and yang. Thus, it harbors silver’s essence, and lead transforms into yellow cinnabar, residing among the five metals as lead. Externally black, it embodies the north’s direction; internally, it harbors metal’s essence, clad in coarse cloth yet holding jade—outwardly a madman.

The *Minister’s Dao* commentary states: "Refining silver from lead, the divine substance generates itself"—white metal has not yet revealed its form, concealed within the northern mysterious water. If one knows how to extract the great medicine’s foundation from within white metal and black lead, and moves according to the celestial patterns, then the divine substance will naturally generate. As the *Cantong Qi* states: "Know the white, guard the black, and the divine illumination will come of itself."

"Silver is the essence of metal; lead envelops the northern numen"—the essence of metal is white metal, and the foundation of mysterious water is true lead. It constantly envelops the true mercury of the northern water. As the *Cantong Qi* states: "The white is the essence of metal; the black is the foundation of water."

"Water is the pivot of the Dao, the beginning of yin and yang, thus harboring silver’s essence"—white metal is born from water and used as a divine vessel. The body of water is inexhaustible, and the mutual affinity of metal and water serves as the pivot, the root of yin and yang. Thus, it is the essence of silver, and the essence of silver is the medicine. As the *Cantong Qi* states: "Water is the pivot of the Dao, its number named the One, the beginning of yin and yang."

"Lead transforms into yellow cinnabar, residing among the five metals"—lead is also called the mysterious position, residing in the Kan direction. The qi of water, fire, metal, and wood converge within lead, making it the master of the five metals and eight stones. When flowing pearls encounter it, they take root, all formed by the congealing of water and fire’s qi. As the *Cantong Qi* states: "The mysterious contains the yellow sprout, the master of the five metals, the northern river chariot."

"Lead is externally black, embodying the north, internally harboring silver’s essence"—lead’s exterior is black and coarse, yet within it lies the golden essence, constantly residing in the northern Ren and Gui positions.

As the *Cantong Qi* states: "Thus lead is externally black yet internally harbors golden essence." "Clad in coarse cloth yet holding jade, outwardly a madman"—before true lead is stabilized through refinement, it lies concealed within ore, its black exterior enveloping inner brilliance, akin to one robed in humble garb yet bearing treasure. The *Cantong Qi* declares: "Clad in coarse cloth yet holding jade, outwardly a madman," precisely this meaning.

The *Chendao Shu* explains: The crucible is the elixir; the elixir is the crucible. Crucible and elixir are one. If the Way of golden liquor could be accomplished without minerals, then those who ingested it would ascend as immortals in great numbers. Thus the *Cantong Qi* states: "Cast aside the eight stones of Wudu, discard them"—from this we know the great elixir employs neither the five metals nor the eight stones, nor malachite, realgar, or cinnabar. As for those golden elixirs that turn from red to purple, they are merely tainted by the qi of malachite or realgar. Moreover, when the primordial qi of nature generates the branches, leaves, flowers, and fruits of plants, their vibrant hues—are these dyed by malachite or realgar? An ancient poem says:

*How wondrous the blooming flower,*
*Red buds amid green leaves—*
*Who has dyed them thus?*
*Know that Creation’s fire*
*Kindles stems and branches,*
*Flowers and leaves unfurling—*
*All transformations wrought by water, fire, and earth’s qi.*

The Way of the golden elixir is likewise: following the principle of Heaven and Earth’s generation, uniting the natural methods of metal and wood, if water, fire, and earth are gathered into one household, how could there be no transformation? Among the myriad arts, some employ the five metals, eight stones, saltpeter, alum, copper powder, and other minerals, yet for the numinous liquor of gold and mercury, such minerals have no application. If those who refine the great elixir comprehend this profound mystery of the Dao and the true lead’s place of origin, then the golden liquor will unfailingly form. Thus the Perfected Liu Zhigu states: "Dragon and tiger are gold and mercury. When golden liquor enfolds them, attaining their natural nature, how could its ingestion not be wondrous?"

**Chapter Twenty-Nine: Silver as the Mother of Lead**
Silver is the mother of lead; the mother resides within lead. Lead is the child of silver; the child conceals the silver’s womb. Ethereal and distant, it seems both present and absent. In the ash pool, with blazing heat, lead sinks while silver floats, pure and white, revealing the treasure that can forge the yellow chariot.

The *Chendao* annotation states: "Silver is the mother of lead; the mother resides within lead"—silver is metal, lead is water. Water is born from metal, and metal in turn conceals its form within lead-water. The *Cantong Qi* says: "Metal is the mother of water; the mother nurtures the child’s embryo," precisely this.

"Lead is the child of silver; the child conceals the silver’s womb"—silver is the child, water; lead is the mother, metal. Since metal generates water, the child-water again dwells within the lead-mother, hence called black lead. The *Cantong Qi* states: "Water is the child of metal; the child conceals the mother’s womb," precisely this. After black lead transforms in quality, it lodges in the west, ever tracing its path within water, where it receives water’s nourishment and increasingly manifests its generative power. Named black lead, when refined into white metal and made into a divine chamber, the yang fire’s stimulation causes the child-water to flow forth from the white metal, called true mercury.

Great indeed! This true substance is the one qi that generates Heaven and Earth.

The true essence, vast and distant, seems both present and absent—this is the true essence, the true mercury. Within the mother’s womb, pressed and pursued by external signs, it flickers between existence and non-existence, rising and sinking without constancy. Concealed by the crucible-chamber, its form and appearance cannot be seen. The *Cantong Qi* states: "The true person’s utmost subtlety is as if present, as if absent," precisely this.

In the ash-pool, flames scorch: lead sinks, silver floats. The ash-pool’s fire blazes, lead sinks below, silver rises above—called white metal. The *True One’s Child* says: The true mercury within the divine crucible, steamed and fumigated by yang fire and yin signs, flies and hides without constancy, now sinking, now floating. The divine chamber is like a great abyss. The *Cantong Qi* states: "Vaguely resembling a great abyss, now sinking, now floating," precisely this.

Pure white, the treasure appears—it can be fashioned into the yellow chariot. The ash-pool forges and refines it into white metal; taking white metal to make the divine chamber, one can craft the yellow chariot. The *Cantong Qi* states: "Gather it when white, fashion it to become vermilion," precisely this.

The *Minister’s Dao in Exposition* says: The essence of golden liquid lies in the divine water, the flower-pool—the flower-pool is the mother of metal. Metal is the white metal of the west; within this metal is liquid mercury. The radiant pearl of the Great Yang and these two substances, though each has its form, share a single source. The perfected person nurtures the metal and mercury, transforming them into cinnabar—this is returning to the root and reverting to the source, restoring the nature of spontaneity. The white metal, divine mother, nurtures the great elixir. Once the great elixir is formed, its fluids never cease, hence called golden liquid. Those who cherish the Dao must examine and scrutinize this carefully. One cannot simply mix mountain silver and mercury and call it "nurturing mercury."

**Chapter Thirty: The Shell Becomes Metal-Essence**
The shell becomes metal-essence; water returns as yellow liquid. A substance the width of an inch blends the Three Powers. Before Heaven and Earth divided, its form resembled a chicken’s egg.

The *Minister’s Dao in Annotation* says: "The shell becomes metal-essence; water returns as yellow liquid"—true lead is refined into white metal, and white metal is made into the crucible-vessel, the mother of metal-essence. Within it lies mercury, which can transform into yellow liquid. The *Cantong Qi* states: "Refined to become its outer defense, white within, the true resides," precisely this.

"A substance the width of an inch blends the Three Powers"—the divine chamber is hollow, square or round, slightly over an inch. The upper cauldron is Heaven, the lower cauldron is Earth, and within, the numinous mercury embodies the Three Powers. The *Cantong Qi* states: "Square and round, an inch in width, blending and supporting one another," precisely this.

"Before Heaven and Earth divided, its form resembled a chicken’s egg"—before Heaven and Earth opened, the primordial chaos was like the shape of a chicken’s egg. The essence of the sun and moon intertwined within it, and the forms of the myriad phenomena began to emerge. The perfected person points to the divine chamber, symbolizing the primordial chaos, to embody the function of the Three Powers. Advancing yang fire and withdrawing yin signs, they retain the essence of the sun and moon. True lead existed before Heaven and Earth; gathering it has its method, crafting it has its principle—it cannot be done recklessly. The *Cantong Qi* states: "Born before Heaven and Earth, majestic and revered," precisely this.

The *Minister’s Dao in Exposition* says: Once white metal is revealed, it resembles white horse’s teeth. Its nature delights in consuming the essence of wood, for wood is born from the water of the north. After forging and refining, it becomes pure as snow—truly the treasure of the elixir. Master Tao says: "Refine treasure with treasure; the aspirant attains the Dao." Ge Zhichuan says: "Stone liquid, demon liquid, metal-essence, mountain treasures"—examining this, it is also "pure white, the treasure appears." Since it is called pure white and also called the treasure, it can be used to craft the golden liquid divine elixir. Today’s people burn cinnabar and mercury; even if they master the method of subduing fire, their fundamental nature remains. Though they may ingest it, how can cinnabar enter the five viscera and disperse like mist, wind, and rain?

**Chapter Thirty-One: Rising High at the Center**
Rising high at the center, its form resembles Penglai. The gates are subtly sealed, the numinous operates within. The furnace and hearth take their form from solid density and complete firmness, bending and restraining one another to ensure no mishap. This is the principle of spontaneity, the divine transformation without limit.

The *Minister’s Dao in Annotation* says: "Rising high at the center, its form resembles Penglai"—in cultivating the great elixir, one must first arrange the altar, furnace, crucible, and hearth, upper and lower connected like the form of Penglai. The *Cantong Qi* states: "Beside it lies a level expanse, resembling Penglai," precisely this.

"The gates are subtly sealed, the numinous operates within"—the crucible’s interior is circular and open on all sides to receive the fire’s qi. The gates are tightly sealed to prevent any loss. The *Cantong Qi* states: "Encircling, sealing, open on all sides, hesitating," precisely this.

"The furnace and hearth take their form from solid density and complete firmness"—on the altar is the furnace, on the furnace is the hearth, in the hearth is the crucible, in the crucible is the divine chamber, and within the divine chamber, metal and water envelop one another to block evil and allow the numinous mercury to arise easily. The *Cantong Qi* states: "Guard and defend, solid and dense, blocking evil," precisely this.

"Bending and restraining one another to ensure no mishap"—the metal crucible hangs within the hearth, its four sides hollowed to disperse the fire’s qi. Water is placed above the metal crucible, fire is moved below the metal crucible, and the altar, furnace, crucible, and hearth envelop one another to prevent accidents. The *Cantong Qi* states: "Curving and joining, connected to guard against mishap," precisely this.

"This is the principle of spontaneity, the divine transformation without limit"—in crafting the great medicine, all are the essence of the sun, moon, and stars, the qi of the Five Phases and Four Images, becoming golden liquid—there is no other Dao.

The *Minister’s Dao in Exposition* says: The perfected person pities those who do not know the Dao, drowning in profit and rushing toward death, unaware of where the numinous goes or where the nature resides. This is why the essence of golden liquid is transmitted. Even the Yellow Emperor and Laozi practiced this Dao, becoming teachers for later generations. Those who ingest the elixir achieve long life, soaring and transforming, entering fire without burning, entering water without soaking—this is it. The rulers who governed before the Yellow Emperor all mastered this Dao, passing it down in succession—not only those who wandered beyond the world pursued this path.

Later generations grew shallow and impure, the method became quite secret, and those who obtained it were rare. By the Zhou dynasty, Laozi descended into the world to cross the Pass, first bestowing the method of golden liquid solely upon the Pass Guardian, the Perfected Yin. From then on, it spread through the world. Those with karmic affinity encounter it and pass it down in succession, unbroken. The seed of the Dao—today’s people are otherwise: wealth and nobility make them arrogant, fame and profit enslave their nature, wine and excess stifle their qi, lust and desire confuse their emotions. Beyond the four pleasures, they fear only death. Thus, they recklessly seek to prolong life, paying homage to masters of arts and techniques in pursuit of the medicine of immortality. Hearing of this, those with devious motives rush in, acting haughtily as if they were masters, remaining silent and secretive, treating the profound as something to be concealed, causing chaos and making the truth difficult to discern. They take peripheral and minor arts, falsely claiming them as the supreme Dao, and borrow the names of minerals, plants, and trees to pass off as true medicine—yet they achieve no effect. That later generations do not believe in the method of golden liquid is hardly surprising.

**Chapter Thirty-Two: The Lodestone Attracts Iron**

The lodestone attracts iron, its influence penetrating barriers in hidden communion—how much more so when the egg’s pairing gives birth? The virtue of metal and earth ever abides with mercury.

Your servant Dao annotates: The lodestone’s power, though whole, can draw several catties of iron beyond vessels—this is the mutual resonance of things. As the *Cantong Qi* states: *"The profound and distant, though separated by barriers, remain connected."* As for the egg’s pairing giving birth: crafting a divine chamber from white metal to resemble an egg’s form, like the union of Heaven and Earth, moving water and fire so that numinous mercury is born. The *Cantong Qi* says: *"Like an egg, black and white support each other."* Moreover, within Heaven and Earth there is the Great Yin’s mysterious essence, transforming myriad forms and infusing all things above. Whether great or small, none exist without it. The perfected refine and consume it to arrest the light and cultivate immortality.

The method to refine it relies solely on white metal, whose power alone can restrain it, allowing it to linger and solidify into transformation. The virtue of metal and earth ever dwells with mercury: metal is Qian, earth is Kun. When Qian and Kun stir in emotion, mercury and lead are born, uniting as golden liquid without fleeing. The *Cantong Qi* says: *"Movement and stillness, rest and activity, ever accompany man."*

Your servant Dao elucidates: The ancient perfected ones’ profound methods lay in refining the golden crucible. If one can comprehend this, one may summon the qi of myriad transformations and know the essence of golden liquid. Suppose, before the primordial chaos, when form and substance were undivided, the state of Heaven and Earth resembled an egg—grasping its root and establishing it as the supreme Dao. Thus, before Heaven and Earth, at the origin of the myriad things, this art was the first attained. Those who obtain it stand alone for eternity, their spirit and form uncorrupted—this is hardly difficult.

**Chapter Thirty-Three: The Fire Record Is No False Composition**

The Fire Record is no false composition, nor does it redundantly reiterate previous texts. Since the elixir arts are already expounded, they are not repeated here; thus, this formula is appended to the Fire Record.

Your servant Dao annotates: The Fire Record is no false composition, nor does it redundantly reiterate previous texts. The Fire Record comprises six hundred chapters, sequentially arranged to operate the ten-month fire regimen. Each month has thirty days, with a hexagram for day and night, totaling sixty hexagrams—ten months thus yield six hundred hexagrams. The second and eighth months also have chapters, but since the third month’s water stabilizes metal and the tenth month’s fire ceases water, they align with the first and seventh months, hence not included in the count. This is the ancient text of the *Dragon-Tiger Classic*, where the Fire Record was transmitted orally by the ancients—no false composition, thus emphasized. As the elixir method states: *"The medicine is transmitted, not the fire."* Since the Fire Record was composed earlier, it is not restated in this scripture, and this formula is appended to it. This scripture was transmitted solely through ancient texts, without recording the author’s name. The ancients who attained the Dao feared the Fire Record would be lost, leaving later generations unable to refine the golden liquid, so they composed this scripture to append to it.

Your servant Dao elucidates: Those who study the Dao in this world fail to grasp the root of golden liquid and cling to peripheral paths, wasting their lives in vain. Some sit rigidly, visualizing, swallowing saliva, inhaling breath, pointing to the Great Abyss as a single aperture, imagining the cinnabar field below the navel, or silently listening for numinous sounds, dividing them into lead and mercury, uniting heart and kidney as water and fire—these are but the studies of beginners. Others practice bedroom arts of qi absorption and supplementation, exchanging yin and yang, exhaling and inhaling, refining inner elixirs—yet as their blood and qi deplete, they invite calamity, their decaying forms turning to dust. Such misguided paths are numerous, all straying from the Dao, advancing yet retreating, hastening yet delaying, obscuring the utmost truth and violating Heaven’s principle. Viewed thus, they are deeply pitiable.

This scripture begins with the dragon and tiger: the dragon is the sun, the tiger is the moon. Sun and moon are the ancestors of Qian and Kun’s movement, the root of the myriad things’ birth. Qian is the metal body of Heaven, its color azure-green, containing yin and yang, harmonizing the four images, the three luminaries, and the two qi, all operating within it. The ancients emulated Heaven and Earth’s movement, the sun and moon’s separation and union, establishing the furnace and crucible, gathering the light of the two luminaries, summoning the dragon and tiger’s qi into the divine chamber, refining it into medicine, called the golden elixir—hence the name *Dragon-Tiger*. Master Wei said: *"The dragon’s spirit sings where the spring’s light clouds weave the sky; the tiger’s roar stirs the void’s rushing wind. The yang burning-mirror shines, crimson fire rises; the yin dew-receiver reveals the mysterious overflow—all occurs naturally."*

The Way of the golden elixir’s transformations is fundamentally one. If one relies on the five metals, eight stones, various lead ores, or visualizations to gather inner elixirs, hoping to ascend in broad daylight, is this not difficult? Moreover, this scripture’s three chapters contain vulgar and coarse language, with some characters incorrect—all later additions under false names. I have excised them, aligning with Master Wei’s *Cantong Qi* to divide it into thirty-three chapters, so later scholars may follow its sequence without error.

Though the mountains and forests harbor lofty recluses, and the court and markets teem with great talents, can there be no hope for those who deeply cultivate the Dao, verifying it against the *Cantong Qi*?

**Ancient Text of the *Dragon-Tiger Classic*, Annotated and Elucidated, Volume Three**
**Fire Regimen of the Great Elixir in the *Cantong Qi***
**Diagram of the Gathered Celestial Fire Regimen**

Gather the celestial fire regimen to align with years, months, days, and hours, following yin and yang to withdraw and add water and fire, so the dragon’s essence gradually descends within the crucible, and the golden liquid flows smoothly within the womb.

**Fire Regimen of the Celestial Cycle**
The mechanism most vital to the golden elixir:
Within the year, follow the moon’s changes;
Within the day, shift with the hours’ movement.
The four seasons share the same process,
The three spirits seem to possess knowledge.
The true secret of fire and metal—
What else can be applied beyond this?

**Fire Regimen of the Great Elixir in the *Cantong Qi***
**Diagram of Metal and Fire Intermingling to Generate Medicine**

**Daily Fire and Monthly Metal: The Convergence of Yin and Yang**

Sun’s fire and moon’s metal unite in the darkness of night,
Their essences intertwined to generate the myriad things.
A month’s cycle concludes, then begins anew,
Since the dawn of creation, endlessly revolving.

Water and fire intermingle to nurture,
Sprouts blossom forth in fragrance.
Golden radiance descends upon Mao’s stars,
The Jade Hare appears within the Heart Chamber.
The waning spirit begins with *xin*,
The soul retreats into the *gen* realm.
The Dao concludes in five and six,
The *Fu* hexagram unfolds once more.

**Postscript to the *Annotated and Expanded Classic of the Dragon and Tiger***
Composed by the Perfected One, Peng Xiao

The *Golden Key* states: When I first divided and analyzed the chapters and meanings of the *Cantong Qi*, I chanced upon an old text and perused the *Songs of the Perfected One of Mount Tai Bai*. Thereupon, I resolved to compose two essays—*Black Lead, the Water Tiger* and *Red Lead, the Fire Dragon*—the essence of which declares:

Black lead, the water tiger, is the root of heaven and earth’s generation, possessing both form and qi. Red lead, the fire dragon, is the origin of heaven and earth’s generation, possessing qi yet devoid of form. These two principles are immutable truths for all eternity.

From the perspective of the Dao, that which has form is not the nine-and-one arts of the yin path—five metals, eight stones, saltpeter, frost, dew, or nectar. That which is formless is not the methods of the six desires, seven emotions, sitting in oblivion, or the visualization of the Three Ones. Thus, the ancients said: That which has form is true lead, the essence of the Grand Yin moon, the mother that nurtures the forms of heaven, earth, and the myriad things. That which is formless is true mercury, the light of the Grand Yang sun, the father that generates heaven, earth, and the myriad things. These two bodies, lead and mercury, mutually engender and cycle without end, truly the ancestors that give birth to heaven, earth, and all things.

Therefore, perfected ones and superior scholars spare no effort in gathering the essence of the Grand Yin, devising symbolic methods to guide the qi of the Grand Yang into the divine chamber, where it coalesces into the divine elixir of golden liquid. The essence of the Grand Yin is the golden blossom, the yellow sprout. The qi of the Grand Yang is the flowing pearl, the enchanting maiden. Thus, the scripture states: *"The flowing pearl of the Grand Yang ever seeks to depart; only when it encounters the golden blossom does it turn and remain."* It also says: *"The enchanting maiden by the river is numinous and most divine. To restrain her, the yellow sprout must serve as her root."* The flowing pearl and enchanting maiden are of restless nature, prone to flight. Without the crucible’s vessel and the skillful summoning of methods, how could they idly abide upon杂物?

Thus, in crafting the great elixir, one must first refine true lead, modeling the divine chamber after heaven and earth. The upper crucible symbolizes heaven, the male, *qian*, *li*, the sun, fire, yang, and wood. The lower crucible symbolizes earth, the female, *kun*, *kan*, the moon, water, yin, and metal. When the two crucibles unite, they resemble an egg, their hollow interior spanning slightly over an inch to house the numinous mercury. Here, *kun* is the mother, the metal wife; *qian* is the father, the wood husband. Once the fire dragon unites beneath the divine chamber, the metal tiger’s essence converges within, their coupling unceasing, their progeny boundless. From wood arises the hun-soul, from metal the po-spirit. Hun and po congeal into qi, gradually forming the *yine* and *e*, their intermingling producing the flowing pearl, called the golden liquid. Thus, the ancient song says:

*"Bind the body, gather the po to sate the tiger’s hunger;
The tiger comes to feed, consuming marrow and fat."*
Marrow and fat are the golden liquid.

One must also seek a numinous mountain or blessed land to construct the elixir chamber, erect a stellar altar, install the furnace and hearth, and cast the crucible chamber. Only when true companions gather and all guidelines are meticulously observed can one proceed with this endeavor. Thus, Master Zhen Yi, in his postscript to the *Cantong Qi*, states: *"The adept must thoroughly relinquish fame and profit, sever worldly ties, retreat to a numinous mountain, and secretly cultivate with like-minded immortals, diligently practicing day and night. Only then may success be hoped for. Otherwise, one’s efforts will be in vain."*

Master Yin Zhen said: *"Without the proper ground, do not act rashly. One must be discreet, cautious, and guarded, preserving the celestial mechanism. This medicine’s transformations are beyond comprehension."* He also said: *"Do not waver in success or failure; with single-minded devotion, refine the returning elixir. Can this be empty words to delude later generations?"*

I, Dao, have encountered a teacher and followed his guidance for many years. Yet, burdened by a minor official post, a humble home, meager salary, and the entanglements of worldly affairs—compounded by a growing household—I have drifted to this point without the means to proceed. Nevertheless, my resolve has not faltered; my heart grows ever firmer. I await only a favorable wind to ultimately accomplish this task.

The nineteen fire-regimen diagrams are all included at the end of the lower volume of the *Cantong Qi*; they are not reproduced here. Only the *Diagram of the Gathered Celestial Fire Regimen* and the *Diagram of Metal and Fire Intermingling to Generate Medicine* are appended to this text, clarifying the dragon and tiger’s movements and verifying the mysterious workings of metal and wood.

On the eighteenth day of the third month in the *yisi* year, I, Dao, was mistakenly summoned by the reigning emperor to discuss the arts of nurturing life and cultivating nature. I respectfully presented my annotations on the *Classic of the Dragon and Tiger* and my supplementary explanations of the *Cantong Qi*, offering my responses. I was graced with the emperor’s jade-like instructions, discoursing on lofty principles at length, fortunately without error or oversight. This was a thousand lifetimes’ blessing from a past existence. In the fourth month of that same year, I was entrusted with an official post in the Imperial Pharmacy, basking in the favor of imperial light. Having completed the transcription and presentation of my annotations on the *Classic of the Dragon and Tiger*, I, a distant and lowly figure, dared not presume to annotate and expand such texts—my transgression is unforgivable. Yet, thanks to the sagely sovereign’s forbearance, I was not immediately dismissed. Upon reviewing my errors, the emperor deemed me worthy of life beyond death.

In my supplementary annotations to the *Cantong Qi*, the explanations are somewhat extensive, and I was unable to present them simultaneously. Constrained by my meager salary and lack of resources, I could not transcribe them to reach the imperial gaze. My reverent heart yearns for the throne, yet I have no means to ascend. Later, I made several revisions and additions. I have now carefully transcribed them separately and commissioned their carving into woodblocks, hoping they may circulate among like-minded practitioners. If encountered, they may serve as a preliminary guide.

Some may say: *"The original text of the *Classic of the Dragon and Tiger* is profound and abstruse; it cannot be lightly discussed. Your annotations, sir, are crude and shallow—how can they be accurate?"* To this, I reply: Since my youth, I have devoted myself to studying texts without respite. Now, at fifty-six, I have encountered a luminous teacher and oral instructions, which I have not failed to refine diligently. If I were to deceive later generations with falsehoods, how could I dare to betray the radiant heavens above?

chunks.original_text: 钦定四库全书　　　　　子部十四 古文龙虎经注防　　　　道家 提要 【臣】等谨按古文龙虎经注防三卷宋王道撰前有道自序及太乙宫道士周真一奏进札子又有道后序一篇道本末不可考自题称保义郎差充恩平郡王府指挥使自序又云一介武弁隶职王府盖本藩邸环卫官而依附道流者也 陈振孙书录解题载古文龙虎上经一卷不着名氏道推衍其义为之注又申注意自为之防其经分三十三章上卷十三章中卷六章下卷十四章末又载攒簇周天火侯金火相交生药二图以明用功之法大防谓真铅真汞止取天地之精日月之华混合造化以成神丹辨药材之真伪抉金石之异同又称得真师口诀以龙虎经行世之本谬误为多故厘而正之分章定句于淳熙间奏进所谓龙虎者即水火之义道家丹诀例用寓名耳 注防中多引参同契语盖炉火之说自魏伯阳始有书犹彼法中之六经也 道又有注参同契见所作后序今佚不然大意亦不过如此矣 此书宋史艺文志不着录或疑出羽流依托然龙虎经之为古书尚无确验亦何必究注之真伪且服气养生山林隐之事也 因方士以奏于朝此何意乎 其人殊不足道姑以其言成理存之耳

The *Imperially Commissioned Complete Library of the Four Treasuries*
**Masters Section, Volume 14**
*Annotated Ancient Text of the Dragon-Tiger Classic*
**Daoist School**
**Abstract**

We, your ministers, respectfully observe: The *Annotated Ancient Text of the Dragon-Tiger Classic* in three juan was composed by Wang Dao of the Song dynasty. It is prefaced by the author’s own preface and a memorial from Zhou Zhenyi, a Daoist of the Taiyi Palace, submitting the work for imperial consideration, followed by a postscript by the author. Wang Dao’s origins remain unverifiable; he styled himself "Bao Yi Lang, Acting Commander of the Prince of Enping’s Residence," and in his preface described himself as "a mere military officer serving in the princely household." Thus, he was originally a palace guard of the princely establishment who later attached himself to the Daoist tradition.

Chen Zhensun’s *Bibliographic Notes with Explanations* records the *Ancient Text of the Dragon-Tiger Upper Classic* in one juan, unattributed to any author. Wang Dao expanded upon its meaning with annotations and further elucidated his intent through supplementary explanations. The *Classic* is divided into thirty-three chapters: thirteen in the upper juan, six in the middle, and fourteen in the lower. At the end are appended two diagrams—*"Gathering the Celestial Fire Phases"* and *"Gold and Fire Intermingling to Generate the Elixir"*—to clarify the method of practice. The main annotations assert that true lead and true mercury are but the essence of Heaven and Earth and the radiance of the sun and moon, harmonized to emulate creation and refine the divine elixir. They distinguish the authenticity of medicinal ingredients and resolve the differences among minerals. The author also claims to have received the true oral instructions of a master, noting that the circulated versions of the *Dragon-Tiger Classic* contained many errors, which he corrected by reorganizing the text into chapters and fixing the phrasing. During the Chunxi era, he submitted the work for imperial review, explaining that "Dragon-Tiger" signifies the meaning of water and fire—a conventional metaphor in Daoist alchemical texts.

The annotations and explanations frequently cite the *Cantong Qi*, for the discourse on furnace and fire originated with Wei Boyang, whose work remains the "Six Classics" of that tradition. Wang Dao also wrote a *Detailed Annotation of the Cantong Qi*, as mentioned in his postscript, though this work is now lost. Its general purport, however, was likely similar to the present text.

This book is not listed in the *Bibliographic Treatise* of the *History of the Song Dynasty*, leading some to suspect it was forged by Daoist practitioners. Yet, as the antiquity of the *Dragon-Tiger Classic* itself remains unverified, there is little need to investigate the authenticity of the annotations. Moreover, the practices of breath cultivation and life nurturing belong to the reclusive traditions of mountain forests—why, then, would a court alchemist submit such a work to the throne? The man himself is hardly worthy of note; we preserve this text merely because its arguments are coherent.
